subdebateinfo.title: Safety of Fire Doors: Notice of Investigation and Warning to the Public

talk.start.para: —by leave—Concerns about the safety of consumers in a large number of high occupancy buildings have led me to issue a notice of investigation and warning to the public under section 65B of the Trade Prac tices Act 1974. The notice advises that a particular type of fire door—that is, fire doors using a Pyrokor core—which were manufactured between 1993 and 3 September 1998 are under investigation to determine whether they will or may cause injury to any person. The notice was published in a special Commonwealth government Gazette on 19 March 1999.

speech.para: Allegations that these fire doors do not meet mandatory building safety standards were first brought to my attention on 22 February 1999. I then asked the Department of the Treasury to obtain urgent technical advice from state and territory building regulators and from the Australian Building Codes Board on this issue and advise me accordingly.

Fire doors are required to satisfy the safety performance requirements of the Building Code of Australia 1996, which requires the doors to impede the passage of fire through a building. This means that fire doors must be manufactured and installed in accordance with part 1 of Australian Standard 1905. In accordance with the Australian standard, fire doors must be subjected to a standard fire test and be fire rated. For example, a fire door with a fire rating of one hour must impede the passage of fire through the door for at least one hour and a two hour fire rated door for at least two. Fire doors, therefore, provide more time to enable the occupants of a building to evacuate in the event of a fire.

I have been provided with copies of fire door certification schedules which claim the Pyrokor fire doors meet the Building Code requirements. However, I have concerns about the validity of the certifications for two reasons. Firstly, a number of the fire test reports being referenced actually show that the Pyrokor fire doors did not obtain the minimum fire rating of one hour. Secondly, test reports on fire doors constructed of different materials were being referenced, and reliance on these test reports would be invalid. Thus the Pyrokor fire doors have been represented as complying with safety requirements when they may not comply.

The ACCC is currently investigating the certificates of compliance for breaches of sections 52, 53A and 55 of the Trade Practices Act which deal with misleading and deceptive conduct and false representations. This may have serious implications for those with responsibility for the inspection and approval of building works. While enforcement of the Building Code of Australia is a state and territory responsibility, the relevant departments responsible for building regulation do not enforce the Building Code of Australia. This is done by local councils, which have the power to approve building construction and declare buildings fit for occupancy or unsafe as the case may be. If councils were led to believe that the doors met required standards they would naturally have approved the buildings. The department has now written to state and territory departments responsible for building regulation and asked that this matter be brought to the attention of local councils.

Under the Trade Practices Act 1974 I have a range of powers to protect the public from unsafe goods. I can publish a notice stating that specified goods are under investigation and warn of the possible risk involved in their use. I can also order the compulsory recall of goods if it appears to me that the goods `will or may cause injury' to any person and the supplier has not taken satisfactory action to prevent the goods causing injury to any person. Fire doors that do not meet the relevant mandatory safety requirements of the Building Code of Australia may not provide the level of safety and protection expected by the community and government.

I have also received expert technical advice from CSIRO that the installation of a Pyrokor door that does not meet the safety requirements represents a varying degree of life and property hazard. The hazard could be extreme in situations where the occupants are asleep or incapacitated—for example, in hospitals and nursing homes. In other occupancies which contain various combinations of smoke detection and fire control systems the risk to life would be considerably reduced, particularly if the buildings were only occupied for work purposes.

I have been advised that Pyrokor fire doors manufactured between 1993 and 3 September 1998 are installed in hospitals, nursing homes, schools, major shopping centres, stores and supermarkets, high-rise home units, government buildings and private business premises. Before considering the need to order a compulsory recall under the Trade Practices Act I need to establish conclusively that the fire doors in question fail the Building Code safety requirements and that those failures actually pose a threat to the safety of occupants of buildings. Minor technical breaches of the safety requirements may not provide sufficient evidence that the Pyrokor fire doors `will or may cause injury' and, as a consequence, lead me to use my powers to order a compulsory recall under the Trade Practices Act.

I have asked the Department of the Treasury, therefore, to commission urgent testing of the fire doors by the CSIRO, to establish conclusively whether or not the fire doors installed in buildings meet safety requirements and to assess the safety implications if the fire doors do not meet Building Code fire test requirements. These tests may provide conclusive evidence on which to base a compulsory recall under the Trade Practices Act. Although there are varying degrees of risk, I am not prepared to take any chances when there is a potential risk to the lives of consumers and have, therefore, issued the notice of investigation and warning to the public under section 65B of the Trade Practices Act 1974. On completion of the investigation and testing of the Pyrokor fire doors I will publish a further notice advising what action I intend to take. I present a copy of my ministerial statement.

talk.start.para: —by leave—On the basis of the information that has been provided to the opposition by the government and that has been outlined in the ministerial statement today the opposition supports the actions taken by the minister. We note that in his statement he indicates that this matter was first drawn to his attention on 22 February of this year. I am presuming from his statement that this can also be read as meaning that this is the first occasion on which the government became aware of the issue and that none of his predecessors have had this issue drawn to their attention. I am also assuming that the assessment that has been made by his departmental advisers that there is insufficient technical evidence at this stage to make a conclusive decision to order an immediate recall is, in fact, a fair and reasonable assessment of the state of that evidence.

speech.para: It is obviously important that the government of the country protects consumers from risks such as fire doors that are portrayed as being able to perform a particular task to a given standard but that are in fact not able to do so. Therefore it is entirely appropriate that such an investigation should be launched and conducted urgently. If the investigation does reveal, as the minister obviously suspects, that this particular category of fire door is not adequate for the purposes for which it is warranted, then clearly a recall should occur.

I note also that these events do raise questions about the certification process which enabled these particular fire doors to be certified as appropriate for the task, when it may well be that they are not. Hopefully the inquiry by the ACCC will cast some light on that question as to whether any changes in procedures are required. It is also a good indication of the importance of rigorous procedures in matters such as these.

I note the tangential reference in the statement to building inspectors. It is one of the concerns that I have that in some areas the processes of inspection and enforcement of some of these types of concerns has actually deteriorated in recent times through, for example, the privatisation or contracting out of things like building inspection.

In conclusion, based on the information that we have at this stage, the opposition supports the actions that the minister is proposing to take. May I just in passing commend the minister for actually making a ministerial statement on this issue rather than using question time to do so. It would be good if some of his colleagues followed his example.
Motion (by Mr Hockey) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The damage being done to Australian tertiary education by the policies of the Howard government.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —`Whoever puts forward this argument, wherever they may be, whoever they may be, is putting forward a mistaken argument.' Who said that? This man, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, said it. He made it quite clear that he believes that that is the view of the old trade unionists.

speech.para: Who made this statement? Was it Laurie Carmichael? No. Was it John Halfpenny? No. Was it John Coombs? No. Was it Joe de Bruin? No, it was the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia who made the remarks in this article—

talk.start.para: —Peter who?

—`Peter who?' the member for Banks may well ask. It was a comment written in this report by the current Treasurer of Australia, Peter Costello. Let me remind the minister exactly what the Treasurer said:

speech.para: The funding and therefore provision of . . . services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution. . .
Peter Costello, Treasurer of Australia today, said that. Minister, you were the one who said that it was the old trade union view. You are the one who said:
Whoever puts forward this argument, wherever they may be, whoever they may be, is putting forward a mistaken argument.
Minister, let me remind you what Mr Costello also said:
The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes.

That is the view of the man who collects the majority of our taxes in Australia today. You cannot make taxes optional; you have got to make sure that everyone pays their fair share of taxes. It is the same with local government rates. You cannot have local government rates being optional or people will not pay their fair share; there will be no revenue to provide the garbage collection services, to look after the services that local government provides. This minister cannot understand his own colleague's commonsense. If the minister wants to get his researchers working on this, the article is in Lot's Wife . There is a bit of a hint for you. See if you can get your researchers to find it in Lot's Wife . In this article the Treasurer goes on to say:

The fact that there are some political donations made on behalf of S.R.C.s . . . does not mean that we should therefore create a situation where all activities including those that are profitable . . . should be penalised by voluntary payments.

Peter Costello got this right when that article was written. The minister for education is getting this argument wrong today. The reason that we are going to oppose this government's vindictive and destructive legislation on student unionism is that we know what is really driving this.

The real reason this minister is launching this attack on student unions is that this minister is fading in the top 30 of the ministerial hit parade. He was Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in the last government and he made such a stuff up of the Job Network he lost half his job. Having lost half his job, he is desperate to try to find a way that he can win back the Prime Minister's love and affection. He wants to win back the Prime Minister's glowing support. We believe that the way you do not do this is to take the meat cleaver to education services in Australia. That is what this government and this minister have done to education services in Australia.

The meat cleaver hacks off $840 million—slashed—from universities' operating advances. It slashes off 21,000 university places, taken away from the forward estimates. This government dramatically puts the blade into all of those students out there who are paying more in their HECS payments. This minister imposes on an arts student who is doing a three-year arts degree an increase of $2,500 in the cost of doing their degree through the higher HECS payments. If you are enthusiastic about maths or science or computing and you want to make a contribution to the future of the country, this Howard government has increased the cost of your three-year maths, science or computing course by $6,700. If you happen to watch one of those TV programs that encourages you to become a vet, this government actually penalises you over your five-year vet science degree by adding an extra cost of $15,290.

They take $840 million from funding for universities. They take 21,000 places out of the forward estimates for universities. They force students to pay thousands and thousands of dollars more. They take half a billion dollars out of the student income support schemes by the unfair changes they have made there and they axe $240 million over four years from the future growth for TAFE. That is how this government demonstrate their concern about education. What they do not understand is that education is an investment in the nation's future. Education is an investment in giving young people more opportunity so that they can not only enrich their lives but also get more opportunities for employment. Every time this minister for education takes a dollar out of a university, takes a dollar out of TAFE, takes a dollar out of the pockets of students, he is denying those young people their opportunities. He is denying all Australians, whatever their age, a chance to retrain during their working life if they happen to lose their jobs. It is this minister for education in this government who is reducing the opportunities for young people right across the country.

We know that this is driven by revenge. This is revenge because the student unions had the temerity to speak out against this government's cutbacks in funding for universities. The student unions, the student associations and the student guilds led the fight against the 1996 budget cuts to education. That is why they have paid the penalty. In the same way, this government axed federal funding for the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Federation because they had the temerity to oppose the government's cuts in funding for nursing homes. They had their funding cut in the same way as the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition had their funding cut because they had the temerity to oppose this government's cuts to student youth support programs. They had their funding cut because they opposed the changes to the youth allowance. In the same way, this minister, in a vindictive and destructive way, is setting out to silence the student unions, the student associations and the student guilds who oppose this government's short-sighted cuts to funding for education.

I suspect that in some measure this has been driven by the fact that some of the student guilds and student associations many years ago made the mistake of including the word `union' in their name. Some of them are called student unions; others are called student associations and student guilds. But I bet that if there were no student organisation across the country called a student union we would not have this legislation before the parliament today.

talk.start.para: —Or if the universities charged amenities fees.

—Or if the universities charged amenities fees, as the Leader of the Opposition interjects, we would not have this legislation here today. This government hate the word `union' as much as this government hate the word `Medicare'. Remember in the last parliament they went out of their way to delete the word `Medicare' from the lexicon of any legislation in the parliament. `Medicare' was deleted from the name of the health care agreements with the states and `Medicare' was deleted from the legislation governing the Medicare payments because they hate Medicare. In the same way as they hate the word `Medicare' they hate the word `union'. I worry about the future of organisations like credit unions and rugby union clubs and the European Union. You have to realise that this is being driven by this minister's ideological obsession. Having lost half of his job, he is determined to try to win back the favour of the Prime Minister.

speech.para: We on this side of the House believe that student associations and student unions have a legitimate role to play. They can speak out on behalf of students. They can speak out to the federal government if they are contemplating changes in the student allowance. They can speak out to the vice-chancellors on campus if they believe there are changes there that warrant a student point of view being put forward. They can also make sure that services are organised to meet the needs of students. That is the role of student associations. You need to have democratically elected student presidents and democratically elected student councils to make sure that they represent the views of their members.

What this minister has never understood is that only five per cent of the funds raised by these fees goes towards that activity—a legitimate activity—while 95 per cent of the money actually goes towards providing services for students and also services to people in local communities like your own, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, right across the country in rural and regional Australia—services such as child care, housing assistance, legal advice and sexual counselling. They help run the cafeterias and the sporting facilities to help people train and become excellent in various sporting pursuits. They also do things that I am sure are important to many of my colleagues on this side of the House. They make sure that there are opportunities to hear bands. The first time some young people get to hear a band is when they are at their local TAFE or university campus. For new and emerging bands it is often their only chance to become well known, given the changes that have taken place in the licensing laws in pubs and clubs.

The minister might look down his nose at those opportunities for Australia's young and emerging musicians, but we on this side of the House know that that is also a small but important part of the role that student unions and student associations play. That is what is at risk because of this minister's ideological obsession—child care, housing assistance, legal advice, cafeterias, sporting facilities, social activities through bands, and the 2,000 or more jobs that are generated in those cafeterias, in the gymnasiums and in looking after the sporting fields. All of those 2,000 jobs are at risk because of this minister's ideological obsession.

We predicted at the start of this debate that members of the coalition backbench would revolt. They already have: the member for Kennedy—I'll read you the press releases if you like—the member for Gilmore, the member for Groom, and we have had the member for New England realise that the cinema in Armidale is run by the student association, while people like the member for Page are working out that the new swimming pool is one-third funded by the local student association. We have people like Steve Moneghetti making it clear that if it were not for competition in the University Games he would not have developed as well as he has as one of Australia's great sporting ambassadors. He realises that this minister, in undermining the sporting opportunities for young people at Australia's universities, is undermining the next generation of Steve Moneghettis, and he is undermining opportunities for young people wherever they may be.

The minister argues and his colleagues argue, `Don't worry. We have implemented so-called voluntary student unionism in Western Australia and it is a great success.' He is over in Washington—he has disappeared on a junket somewhere—so he rolls out Senator Lightfoot. You know that you are really in trouble when you have to roll out Senator Lightfoot to defend you. Senator Lightfoot says, `It is such a success in Western Australia. I know of one university campus where they have closed down the child-care centre and opened a hairdressing salon.' That is how this minister defines success. He also claims there was an expansion of employment services at Curtin University, I think it was, but when you actually looked at the figures the minister had once again misled the Australian people. He had misled the Australian people because it was not a new, broader service; it was actually a more restrictive service.

You used to be able to get your CV written for free at Curtin University but now you have to pay money. Employment advice was available to every student on campus before but it is now only available to the 10 to 20 per cent who are members of the student union. This minister misled the Australian people when he claimed that there was a new employment advice service at Curtin University when in fact voluntary student unionism meant that there had been a restriction in the ability of students at that campus to get the employment advice they needed.

We believe very strongly that this minister should be held accountable for his attack on voluntary student unionism. We are also going to make it clear that when this minister attacks Australia's university system he is attacking the very thing that provides Australia's opportunities for the future. When young people get a chance to improve their skills, they get a chance to be part of the new discoveries and the new inventions that are coming along. When young people study maths and science, that gives them a better chance to be part of the future research and development that is there to provide jobs for the future. When young people make an effort to do maths, science and history and to learn about their country, they are not only enriching themselves but also giving themselves the best possible start in life and the widest possible choice of opportunities for their future.

When this minister lops $840 million from university funding, he is cutting into those opportunities for young people. When he cannot make up his mind about the future of the Australian Research Council after months and months of dithering, he leaves at risk our future research effort. This minister cannot make up his mind and cannot convince his colleagues what is going to happen on the question of supplementation for universities. He raised their hopes towards the end of last year and then dashed them when he met with them this year. Is it any wonder that the universities do not know how much more pain and suffering students and staff will suffer under this minister's reign?

On issues like Greenwich University on Norfolk Island the minister cannot even be bothered to talk to his colleague to stop Australia's international reputation being undermined. The problem with this government is that they do not understand that funding and education are an investment in the future. They are not a cost; they are an investment. They are an investment in the future of young Australians. They are an investment in the future of our fellow Australians in making sure that they have the opportunities they need in life and the opportunities Australia needs for a healthy future.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The invisible man of the Australian education debate, the shadow minister, has finally dared to put up a topic in the House for debate. But when we look at the substance of what he has to say we find that, as you expect with the Labor Party, there is one overwhelming preoccupation, and that preoccupation is the defence of the union interests behind the Labor Party—in this case, the National Union of Students. There are many issues that the shadow minister might have addressed to tell us what the Labor Party is going to do. We know he is a shadow minister saddled with an empty, vacuous policy that the member for Werriwa was impelled to walk away from after the last election campaign.

speech.para: When we finally get this shadow minister to his feet in a matter of public importance debate, we are not at all surprised to find that the topic which preoccupies him is the compulsory funding of his mates on campus. He is not interested in the wider questions relating to higher education. He has never asked me a question about higher education on mainland Australia since the parliament returned this year. I think he attempted to ask a couple of questions about Norfolk Island—and he seems to have returned to the mainland—but he still has nothing whatever of substance to say about Australian higher education policy. That is because the Labor Party has no policy of any worth whatever to do with higher education.

This was made quite clear by the member for Werriwa when he described the circumstances under which the Labor Party's higher education policy was drafted. Let me remind the House of what those circumstances were. The member for Werriwa said:
Mike Pezzullo, chief policy adviser, and John Angley, who worked for Kim as finance minister and had no involvement in the education area, rewrote the bloody thing—
That language is not mine; that is the language of the member for Werriwa, and that refers to the Labor Party's education policy—
all under the approval of McMullan. So they stuffed it up.
The member for Werriwa went on to say:

I first read the final document in the car going from the Frankston launch to Melbourne airport to go home. That is the truth of it, the God's honest truth. Yes, you can quote me. I'm now dealing in the truth.

That is the context within which the member for Dobell, who has responsibility for this massacred and butchered policy of the Labor Party, gets up to make his first speech this year on higher education in the matter of public importance debate.

The topic refers to tertiary education. The great bulk of tertiary education that concerns most young people in Australia once again did not get a mention by the Labor Party. Some 70 per cent of young people do not go on to university. This government has worked to increase very substantially the opportunities for those 70 per cent who do not come out of school and go to university. But, as we know, the Labor Party has no interest in these matters. It has only been concerned with the interests of its union mates on university campuses, so it is not surprising that that preoccupies the member for Dobell.

In relation to voluntary student unionism, the member for Dobell says that student services and student life have in some way declined in Western Australia. Western Australia is a state which has legislated voluntary student unionism and indeed has legislation which is very similar to the legislation the federal government has introduced into the House of Representatives and to the Senate. In relation to Western Australia, I was very interested to read the orientation handbook of the voluntarily funded student association on campus at the University of Western Australia. What that student association handbook said was that the association on that campus was one of the most vibrant in Australia. It offered students a great range of services, and indeed discounts, to encourage them to join the student association.

Once students are given the choice of whether or not to pay a fee to student associations, we expect those associations to improve their services and offer discounts. Once students have that choice, it is incumbent on those associations to make their services responsive to what students are looking for.

But the Labor Party has never supported choice: the Labor Party wants compulsion. Typical of the pathetic props upon which it seeks to rely, the Labor Party goes right back to pick up a student comment from one of the strongest proponents of voluntary student unionism in Australia, the federal Treasurer. The federal Treasurer has been one of the strongest supporters of the abolition of compulsory student unionism. But the member for Dobell seeks to drag out of the distant past a statement which has clearly been disowned by the Treasurer. I am sure that, on reflection, the Treasurer would agree with me that the dragging out of that statement is really characteristic of what we have come to expect from the Labor Party.

Australian universities are outstandingly good institutions. Australia has an outstandingly good university sector, and overseas students are perhaps the best judges of its quality. It is very interesting that under this government we have seen increasing numbers of overseas students coming to Australian university campuses. In fact, last year the number of overseas students was 15 per cent up on the previous year. That reflects, of course, the entrepreneurial attitudes that Australian universities are now taking.

The Australian higher education sector is a growing one. There were 26,000 more undergraduates on university campuses in Australia in 1998 than there were when the Labor Party was last in office in 1996. Total revenues of Australian universities this year, 1999, are the highest ever. They have been estimated to be $8.7 billion, some $700 million more than when the Labor Party was last in office. That reflects the fact that the government has opened the doors to increasing revenues for Australian universities. There have never been more students on campus. Universities have never had more revenue at their disposal than they have under the policies of this government.

Because of the growth that is taking place in higher education, there are more opportunities for disadvantaged students on university campuses. In 1998 the number of indigenous students was up 12 per cent, the number of rural students on university campuses was up seven per cent and the number of disabled students was up 68 per cent from when the Labor Party was in office. So equity of admission to Australian universities is improving and the numbers of such admissions are increasing under this government.

This growth and these expanding opportunities on Australian campuses are occurring because of the government policies underpinning them. In 1999 the operating grant per fully funded student on Australian campuses was $11,596—higher in constant dollar terms than it was when this government came to office. Not only is the funding per fully funded place higher, but also there are more fully funded places. Indeed, there are 13,000 more fully funded undergraduate places on Australian campuses this year than there were when the Labor Party was last in office.

Research funding has also been expanded. The Labor Party made it clear—in that disastrous policy that I mentioned for which the member for Dobell is still responsible—that it did not intend to maintain funding for research on Australian university campuses. The coalition made it clear that it would maintain funding for high quality, basic research in Australian universities.

The government has expanded universities; its policies are leading to an expansion of opportunities for young Australians. The government has supported significant new developments. The member for Fisher would be very interested in these developments because Australia now has a new independent university on the Sunshine Coast.

talk.start.para: —It's opening shortly.

—Indeed, it is being opened shortly. The government has also expanded significantly, through improved funding arrangements, the higher education opportunities for indigenous students in the Kimberleys. A great deal that is exciting and innovative is now going on in the higher education sector.

speech.para: But the member for Dobell cannot see that. He is the member who has been prepared to shoulder the burden of carrying the Labor Party's butchered education policy. When he finally gets up to speak in the parliament, all he can do is talk at length about the interests of his union mates on campuses. He has no interest whatever in the substance of these issues.

The higher education sector is facing significant challenges at the moment; there is no doubt about that. Like other sectors of Australian society, it has had to shoulder some of the burden of coping with the $10.3 billion black hole that was left by the Labor Party's mismanagement. There are students on campus today who very keenly advocate a shift away from the compulsory up-front fee which the Labor Party continues to support for these student unions. Students on Australian campuses, I believe, are looking forward to having freedom of choice over whether or not they will continue to devote that compulsory fee, which on some campuses is well in excess of $300—

talk.start.para: —How much?

—Three hundred dollars—to these student unions that the Labor Party supports or whether, before coughing up that money, they will demand a better spread of services to meet their needs from these unions.

speech.para: The Labor Party supports the only compulsory up-front fee that most students face on university campuses today. Why is the Labor Party the supporter of that compulsory up-front fee? Because it is the union party. As we know, about 14 per cent of Australians belong to unions. But 100 per cent of Labor Party members belong to unions, and all they are ever interested in are the policies that they get from the ACTU and their union affiliates.

That is why we have this extraordinary distortion in the nature of their interests in relation to tertiary education in Australia. The topic for today's matter of public importance is that of tertiary education. What has the member for Dobell said about the tertiary education opportunities for the 70 per cent of young people who do not go on to university? He said nothing whatsoever about that. He said nothing whatsoever about the way in which the Labor Party set out in office to destroy the post-school apprenticeship opportunities for young Australians. He has not taken any note of the fact that, since this government began its policy of growth through efficiencies, the number of places in Australian TAFEs has gone up by over 86,000.

There are now many more students in post-school apprenticeships than there were when the Australian Labor Party was in office. There are many more students at TAFE. There are many more students on Australian university campuses. That is because this government believes that tertiary education is a key to the future of this country. We put in place policies designed to expand opportunities in Australian tertiary education for young Australians. We are ensuring that those opportunities are there for the most disadvantaged among those young Australians, those disadvantaged students neglected by the Labor Party when in office.

This government has a vision for higher education in Australia. The Labor Party has no policy and no vision. When the Leader of the Opposition went to the CEDA organisations to deliver his visionary speech on Australia, I think he gained about half a dozen people who were not members of the Labor Party at that particular function. I noticed when the member for Dobell was giving his speech that about 20 out of the 60 members of the opposition were behind him on the back benches.

talk.start.para: —Are they all on yours?

—Well, they are not interested in your topic. You had very little support from your members during your speech when you initiated the topic. This government cares for higher education; the Labor Party does not. (Time expired)

—It is interesting to hear the comments of the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs today. One can understand why he would want to focus on any issue other than tertiary education—anything other than his performance in question time today. Just yesterday we had the Oscars. I was watching a bit of the Oscars last night, and I saw Roberto Benigni receive the Oscar for best actor. He jumped up, climbed on the seats and punched the air—very much like the minister when he received that first question on the VSU today. After about question 10 on our side, the minister was not looking quite so happy. He looked more like someone who had been nominated but who had missed out.
—He thinks he is a success.

—The shadow minister interjects that he feels that he did well. I do not know what he is feeling, but fantasy land might be the case. The minister does remind me sometimes of a character out of a Spielberg movie. Jurassic Park comes to mind.

speech.para: Mr Slipper interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As for the member for Fisher, we all know which movie he comes out of, and it did not even get nominated. The minister has raised a couple of issues here. Why are we talking about this today? It is very simple, Minister. You have legislation before the House this week. I thought if we have legislation before the House maybe we ought to talk about it. Maybe we ought to consider it. When it is far-reaching legislation, legislation that will have an impact on the operation of tertiary education in this country on an ongoing basis, maybe we ought to talk about it.

speech.para: The minister also said that the shadow minister has never asked him a question. He has, but he cannot get an answer. None of us can get an answer. One could argue that previous shadow ministers in this area have faced boredom and frustration when it comes to getting an answer out of this minister. We talked about the fact that he is fading in the context of the current ministry. For the amount of time he spends gazing into the Prime Minister's eyes, you would be surprised. Possibly it is the fact that the message has not changed over three years that even the Prime Minister is getting tired—tired and upset at looking into those cold eyes. Talking about movies, Count Yorga the vampire springs to mind.

When the minister rose to speak in answer to our questions he basically caused himself a severe amount of problems. That relates to comments on the record historically by the Treasurer of this country. I am a trade unionist; I am proud to admit it. I am surprised that the Treasurer was so reticent to admit it. I thought the only sleeper we had on the other side of the House was the member for Bradfield, but we also have the member for Higgins. Higgins, as honourable members would know, is named after a distinguished judge and jurist who played an important role in the history of the labour movement in terms of fair wages in the Harvester case, but I always thought it was a seat held by the tories. In fact, it is not. It is held by one of the key unionists in this country—an old style unionist, to quote the minister. Obviously on that basis he was a good trade unionist. I would like to go to what that old trade unionist, Comrade Costello, said. Can I use that term? I probably had better not.

talk.start.para: —Mate! Use the word `mate'.

—He is a mate. Before I go to his comments, I want to make a couple of points. The minister talks about the fact that this was some time ago. There is a time limit on truth, is there? If you say something some time ago, because of a change of position or a change of circumstances or a change of belief or a change of trousers, the man has changed his view. The interesting thing is that when he said this he was actually able to make a proper judgment on this issue. He was operating within the tertiary education sector. He was not cutting the guts out of it, but he was there as a student representative. I would have thought in those times he would have a better idea of, he would be in touch with, the concerns of the people he represented at that time. But, no, there is a time limit on truth with this minister and I suspect with the Treasurer.

speech.para: Let me quote the sorts of things that he said during that time. I will be selectively quoting, let me say that up-front. There are things here I will not say, because it is a long article. But I think you will find the whole thing very interesting. Here are a few titbits for you:
Again on the issue of compulsory unionism the Council, in my opinion, took a reasonable attitude.
It was not recommending the abolition of it, not at all. The article goes on:

. . . since the various student unions do have a positive contribution to offer to student welfare and student education they should be supported by all those who profit from them. It seems reasonable that all those who do profit should make some contribution in return. The funding and therefore provision of the various student services would be impossible unless there was some requirements to pay a contribution towards them.

The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes. The fact that there are some political donations made on behalf of S.R.C.s and A.U.S. that may be abhorrent to some people who have contributed union fees does not mean we should therefore create a situation whereby all activities including those that are profitable to the people concerned are financially penalised by voluntary payments.
. . . the facilities of student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions . . .

talk.start.para: —Who makes those contributions?

—Those comments were made by that famous, well-known, old-style trade unionist, Peter Costello—Comrade Costello. I draw another comment from an earlier article, which shows a very fetching picture of the young Costello. It states:

speech.para: In some sort of recognition that education is wider than this academic brain-stretching, the University also provides the Union for "non-academic education"—for interaction between staff and students, and to cater for the physical requirements of academic aspirants.

The Union is also a recognition that knowledge is integral and that separate academic disciplines are divided in an arbitrary way. The Union attempts to bring students of various faculties together, so there is an exchange of learning.

What is proposed under this minister is a situation of severely restricting the capacity for that sort of exchange to occur. We go to the comments made today by the minister in his Roberto Benigni style performance. On the first question the minister said:
. . . I make the general point about voluntary student unionism that one should never assume that funding for student services will cease to flow once voluntary student unionism is in place.
Let us contrast that directly with comments by the Treasurer—that old trade unionist—on this point:
. . . the facilities of student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions—

So at that time in the circumstances of that old trade unionist, who is now the Treasurer of this country, operating in the tertiary education sector in a position of authority and responsibility, he knew very well that the impact of situations such as what is proposed in this legislation—the VSU—would severely hamper the provision of those sorts of services.

talk.start.para: —You are running out of steam.
—There is one thing for sure: the member for Fisher will never run out of steam, and we know what the steam is coming off. In answer to the next question, the minister states:

speech.para: Many students on university campuses are disgusted at the way in which their compulsorily acquired fees are used to promote extremist causes . . .
To take another quote with respect to this issue:
The answer is to get students involved and to stop these payments being made in the first place or to make some constitutional provision . . .

and so on. What the Treasurer says and what the Treasurer did—and I do not agree with all that he did; that is for sure—was to take up the issues of what happens in student unions and basically seek to make changes, not sit back and endeavour to avoid it but to take up these issues. That is what people should be doing in a democratic context within the tertiary institutions of this country. But that is not what is happening here. We have a situation where the government intends to move on the issue themselves.

When we look around that side of the chamber, we see, as the shadow minister has said, a range of members who are starting to raise concerns on these sorts of issues, because the truth of what this legislation means to them and their areas is now starting to dawn on them. A number of members, particularly in regional areas, have concerns about the services provided for their communities. They are starting to understand that, in their electorates, in the places where they live, the people that they say they care about are in danger of having services removed as a result of this legislation and the action by this government.

We talked today about the VSU because it has wider implications than just this issue; we talked today about the VSU because it is an important part of what is happening to tertiary education in this country; we talked about the VSU today because it shows the situation of this minister—the Roberto Benigni of this government—in a situation where he is out of step. When it comes to an Oscar today, this minister will get no lifetime achievement award with respect to his performance in tertiary education. Maybe comedy and, from the way he speaks, maybe a foreign language award—but that would be about the extent of it.

talk.start.para: —I find it quite interesting that the opposition should berate the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs for daring to talk about something other than voluntary student unionism. This is the topic that you folks in the opposition chose to speak about today: was potential damage being done to Australian tertiary education by the policies of the Howard government? What are we supposed to think here—that we have one policy? I know you would like to think that we have only one policy, but you are getting our side mixed up with your side. The policy making on this side of government has to do with benefiting people in tertiary education—not just voluntary student unionism.

speech.para: The other side bring up the old local government argument. It is totally ludicrous. In my humble opinion I think we are overgoverned already. Should we perhaps legislate that all year 12 students should have to pay some sort of levies to their schools so they can provide bands for the school? Where does it end?

talk.start.para: —They do pay levies. What are you on about?
—Year 12 students paying a compulsory levy to their schools to gets bands into their school? It is quite ludicrous.

speech.para: I find it amazing that a member of the opposition front bench would start taking pot shots at a minister on our side for actually working with their leader. It would seem that they are ready to shoot themselves in the feet because, when we look at the front bench over there, it is very hard to tell which leader they support. It is good to see that the ministers on our side do support their leader.

We talk about democratic elections of union presidents at university. Surely democratic elections mean that when we vote for union presidents, union chairmen or union secretaries we have a choice. That is what this legislation is all about. It is democratic. If you want to avail yourselves of the services provided by the student unions then you pay the levy. If you want to participate in democratic elections of the union hierarchy then you do so by choice.

We talk about the cost of HECS, but it appears to me that the Labor Party wants to charge people who have the potential to earn a higher income in their post-university days exactly the same fees as those people who only have the potential to earn a lower income in their post-university days. Perhaps the opposition would like to transfer this sort of thinking into the tax system. Wouldn't that be popular?

I do not know why a member on our side would support such a view. I do not have a problem with anyone on this side of the House or anyone on that side of the House learning, evolving and perhaps changing their views over the years. I would encourage people to listen to argument, talk about and debate it, and evolve an opinion; not just come into this place with a blinkered way of thinking with no intention whatsoever of opening their minds to any other suggestions.

Under the coalition government increased numbers of students have access to undergraduate university education. In 1999 there will be 13,000 more Commonwealth fully subsidised places than there were in the last year of the Labor government. This will increase to 15,000 more by the year 2001. In 1998 university enrolments reached a record high under coalition policies.

In 1987 a green paper nominated 125,000 graduates per year as a target for the year 2000. I would like to congratulate those on the other side for actually achieving this target seven years earlier than anticipated. Since 1995 total university enrolments have increased from 604,000 to 671,000. We are moving ahead; we are not just satisfied with reaching a position and staying there.

There is no doubt that many students do benefit from the services offered by student unions, whether through the use of sporting facilities or services such as the cafeteria, child care or advice on tax or accommodation. The argument is that, if you do not play sport or do not have children and you take a packed lunch to uni, should you have to pay for all these services? Part-time students who study at home and only attend uni for a few weeks of the year are even less likely to benefit from these amenities.

Giving people who are less financially well-off the choice of whether or not to pay these fees of up to $350 per year will mean that they may choose to keep their money in their pockets. We are talking about people who are less financially well-off who may choose to keep their money in their pockets. Is this a bad thing?

My belief is that many of these student unions underestimate themselves. If they were to focus on providing services that the majority of students find useful or appealing, then the students would pay for them. If the services offered are not useful, then they will not. It is quite simple.

The coalition is examining voluntary tests for graduates so that employers, universities and students can have a common assessment of student abilities. During this MPI we are discussing the policies of the Howard government and its involvement in Australian ter tiary education. The coalition is pursuing a strategy of increasing total university resources by encouraging greater private funding of the universities. This will give universities access to larger amounts of revenue and increase their independence. The total annual income is up $550 million since 1995, which was Labor's last full year.

Under the coalition government, as the universities become more deregulated, there will be greater pressure on universities to maintain and improve teaching standards. I point out that total research funding for higher education is up from $399 million in the last year of Labor to $460 million in 1998. This is Howard government policies influencing tertiary education.

I wish to talk about one of the initiatives instituted by the Howard government to expand the role of universities in regional Australia. The construction of a permanent campus at the Charles Sturt University in Dubbo will become a reality in the new year, with the announcement of a $3 million capital development grant from the federal government. This new funding adds to the $1 million already allocated by the government for 1999, and a further $5 million commitment from the university for the project.

The new campus will be built on the Yarrandale Road site. It is a state-of-the-art complex where new technology will be the main feature. The stage 1 plan includes an interactive learning centre which will feature large student work areas complete with computers, Internet and interactive video access. A microwave link already established at the existing Dubbo campus will be extended to the new site providing a high quality telecommunication link between CSU's main campuses in Albury-Wodonga, Bathurst and Wagga Wagga and into Sydney.

This is an example of the Howard government's involvement in tertiary education. This is a very exciting year for the university in Dubbo, not only because of the construction of the campus but also because of the development of new courses from the faculties of health studies and education. This campus in Dubbo will have a new, super high school, a TAFE college and the university campus combined on the one site.

This is the future of education. This is the tertiary advancement we are seeing under the Howard government. Also offered at the university Dubbo campus will be a Bachelor of Business in accounting for both full-time and part-time students, a Bachelor of Nursing, a Bachelor of Health Science, a graduate certificate in small and medium enterprise management and a graduate certificate of applied science. The graduate certificate of applied science includes a diploma in invertebrate management which links with the Western Plains Zoo in Dubbo. The potential for this university in Dubbo to be developed as an internationally recognised facility is boundless.

This is the vision of the Howard government. I commend the Howard government and the Liberal-National coalition for pushing Australian tertiary education to the limit, using new technology, and questioning what we have done in the past and not blindly following it. We can look forward to a vibrant and exciting future across the whole of Australia.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to say that the opposition is fully supportive of the amendments to the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . Essentially, the bill is to overcome a hurdle that exists in section 11(4) of the primary act which prevents the government from spending money on promoting anything other than a formal yes or no campaign in a referendum. In order to spend the amount of money which the government has indicated—some $15 million—for two committees to present arguments in favour of and opposed to the referendum questions that will take place later in the year, it is necessary to overcome that impediment. Similarly, the government has indicated its intention to spend some $4½ million to conduct an education campaign about our system of government generally to Australians. We think that expenditure is also appropriate and hence we support the bill.

speech.para: The other amendments are relatively minor but they are ones of which we approve. Currently, the act provides for the circulation of material only to voters. We think it is appropriate that there be a broader distribution of this historic material than that. Similarly, allowing the transmission through electronic technology brings the act into the 21st century. The other amendment is relatively minor and preserves the secrecy of votes by referring to a referendum question rather than to a voter. That also is supported.

But in supporting the bill there are a number of points that I would like to make. In the second reading speech of the Attorney-General on 11 March, he gave some background to this bill and specifically why it is needed in the context of the referendum which will take place later this year. As the Attorney-General pointed out, the referendum later this year will consider proposed legislation to amend the Constitution to implement a republic system of government based on last year's Constitutional Convention's recommendation for a bipartisan appointment of a president. We in the opposition are entirely supportive of that. It will allow an Australian citizen of some notoriety, fame and respect to be appointed by a joint motion of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition and with a two-thirds majority of a joint sitting of the House of Representatives and the Senate.
Mr Slipper interjecting—

talk.start.para: —My friend opposite said it will be a person of notoriety. It will indeed be a person of substance, a person who has cross-party respect. By definition, a person with cross-party respect will not be one of the political warriors for either of the parties. So Australians, through the Constitutional Convention model, will end up with an Australian as our head of state who will not be a politician and there will be no further changes to our system of government. That is the essential crux of what Australians should bear in mind when they are considering matters later in the year.

speech.para: The government also proposes a public education campaign. As I indicated in my opening, that, we say, is entirely appropriate. It is clear that Australians need to be educated about our system of government. Regrettably, there is remarkable ignorance on the part of many Australians, not only children. For instance, in 1993, a report by Quadrant Research showed that some 50 per cent of people questioned either did not know or gave an incorrect answer when asked how the Australian Governor-General is chosen. Indeed, when asked the meaning of the term `constitutional monarchy', 70 per cent of those interviewed did not know the answer or gave the wrong answer. I understand a survey was conducted more recently on behalf of the government which disclosed similar results.

So there is a remarkable ignorance in our community about the structure of the Constitution, and I will briefly mention a couple of points that people commonly overlook. For instance, section 1 of our Constitution specifically says that our system of government is the Queen, a Senate and a House of Representatives. The Queen is very much a part of our system of government—that is, the Queen who is a citizen of Great Britain, not a citizen of Australia.

talk.start.para: —She is not a citizen of anywhere.

—My friend says she is not a citizen anywhere. She is certainly not an Australian citizen. The fact is that the Queen may disallow any law under section 59 of the Constitution within one year of the Governor-General's consent. Section 61 of the Constitution provides that the executive power of the Commonwealth is vested in the Queen.

speech.para: These are all things that very much confirm that the Queen, who is not an Australian citizen, has a significant role in our system of government. It is important that people realise this. It is far more than a trivial issue; it is very much how we perceive ourselves, how we want to have ourselves governed and, in particular, whether we want a foreign citizen to be far more than merely a symbolic head of state for Australia. These are things that are worth while bringing out in an education campaign.

Equally, there is remarkable ignorance about the rules of succession applying to the British monarchy. It is commonly overlooked that those rules of succession, for instance, provide that Roman Catholics and persons marrying Roman Catholics are excluded by statute from the throne and, further, that the monarch must be in communion with the Church of England and declare himself or herself to be a Protestant and swear to maintain the established churches in England and Scotland.

These things commonly are not appreciated. These are principles that I would go so far as to say are objectionable to Australians and contrary to section 116 of the Constitution, which provides that no person shall be disqualified from any office or public trust under the Commonwealth by virtue of their religion. So it is important that Australians realise the historical basis to the rules of succession which do not have any relevance at all to how Australians perceive themselves and how Australians want to be governed.

Further, Australians need to be educated about our system of government, which is based on a principle of responsible government whereby ministers who constitute the executive are responsible to the parliament rather than a head of state. For instance, in the United States of America, the President appoints the executive, but the executive in Australia must first be elected as members of parliament before they can be appointed as ministers. Their responsibility is demonstrated most graphically, I suppose, in circumstances when a minister misleads the parliament. Custom has it that such a minister has an obligation to resign his office. That is a manifestation of the principle of responsible democracy that we have in Australia. These things will not be changed by virtue of Australia becoming a republic, and it is important that the education campaign the government will be conducting makes that clear.

As the Attorney-General indicated, the referendum bill which has now been put on the table for public comment—and we indicate our agreement that that is the appropriate course for the government to follow—proposes the Constitutional Convention model whereby, as I have said, there will be a bipartisan appointment of a president based on the recommendation of a nomination committee. That committee will be constituted by representatives of the federal parliament, representatives of the state parliaments, representatives of the Territory parliaments and 16 citizens who will be chosen from the community.

We have some concerns with the fact that, under the bill which has been circulated, the Prime Minister will have the role of selecting those citizens. We say that is contrary to the bipartisan spirit that should apply to this whole process. Perhaps a preferable model would be one whereby each of the major political parties has the option of ruling out some of those persons proposed by the other side of the political fence—much the way a jury is selected, for instance. In that way, a core of 16 people who are more acceptable to both sides would be selected. These are things which we would like to discuss with the government in the coming months and through the processes that will be set in train.

The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, spoke of the three phases of this referendum proposal. The first will be the education function, which I have already addressed. The second will be the campaign phase. The Attorney-General indicated that that will be a period of some three to four weeks immediately before the referendum, where two committees that have been chosen will expend their money in communicating their opinions to the Australian people.

We are a little concerned that that period of three to four weeks may be too short. We are of the view that the committees should be given a broader discretion should they wish to commence an earlier campaign than that. However, we think the amount offered is appropriate and, equally, we think the independence given to the committees to choose the manner and mode of advertisement is appropriate, noting that the government will require them to comply with any statutory regulation or advertising code and, of course, we surmise some auditing and accounting obligation. So that procedure is appropriate.

It is noteworthy that the government found it unnecessary to further amend section 11 of the principal act to provide a mechanism for preparation of the `no' case in each of the referendum questions that will take place later in the year, presumably on the assumption that a coalition member or coalition members will oppose the bill to provide for Australia to become a republic and also oppose the bill for a new preamble to the Constitution. That is something the government must consider, but presumably they have those methods worked out.

The third point I note from the Attorney-General's address, which I have referred to, is why there is a need to amend section 11(4) of the principal act. As the Attorney-General said, that section was established as a statutory prohibition against the government of the day funding partisan involvement in campaigns surrounding a referendum proposal. We say that is a sound principle that should not lightly be departed from and, in supporting this bill, we note that the bypassing of the existing restriction will apply only to this referendum and only to this year.

In our view, it is a fundamental principle that the government of the day should not be allowed to advance party political issues through the expenditure of taxpayers' funds. Indeed, the High Court has said that, while a minister has an extremely broad discretion in how they perform their duties, that discretion is not unfettered; they have an obligation to exercise their duty bona fide in the interests of the Australian people. That duty is akin to the fiduciary obligation owed by company directors to companies and trade union officials to trade unions, and it is a fundamental principle of that fiduciary obligation that such an officer is unable to use the resources of the company or the organisation to support their own candidature in an election or their own party political position.

We say that it is appropriate for the Attorney-General to acknowledge the importance of that provision in section 11(4) of the principal act. However, in noting that in form, we would ask the government to have regard to it in substance. I note that the Courier-Mail published an article yesterday comparing the expenditure of major corporations in Australia to the government's expenditure prior to the last election—some $19 million on its GST campaign to promote a party political position. This expenditure rivalled any of the major corporations in Australia. The $8 million of that amount which the government spent in the two weeks before the election was in excess of that spent by Toyota, McDonald's and Coca-Cola combined. That was a massive amount of taxpayers' money spent. So it is somewhat hypocritical for the government to note the importance of section 11(4) in the context of this debate but depart entirely from those principles in the context of its overall conduct as a government. They are fundamental principles that the government should apply right across the board.

The other noteworthy thing in the Attorney-General's speech was that the funding of the campaigns will not apply to the question as to whether Australia votes to have a new preamble. That, we anticipate, is on the assumption that there will be bipartisan support for a preamble which will be advanced in the government's bill. However, the conduct of the government to date has been more than disappointing. It is extremely concerning that there has been a lack of bipartisan input to the drafting of a preamble and, indeed, a lack of appropriate consultation with the community.

In particular, the draft preamble, which the Prime Minister issued at about lunchtime today, departed from the Constitutional Convention's recommendation in respect of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. The Constitutional Convention recommended that the preamble be amended to specifically include acknowledgment of the prior occupation of Australia's shores by native Australians and the custodianship by those indigen ous Australians. The government has overlooked that very important and, one might say, fundamental principle that the Constitutional Convention recommended in attempting to have this preamble as an important step towards reconciliation with indigenous Australians. We hope the government has circulated its document very much as a draft and not as a fait accompli.

In that context, we note that the Attorney-General, in a speech that was televised on 6 February, gave a commitment that there would be a parliamentary committee—probably a joint select committee—established to review the two bills which will contain the referenda questions to be submitted to the House. We hope that that committee process will be permitted to be one which is bona fide and open and that the government will have regard to the outcome. If that does not occur, it will be a farce. The proposal of a preamble that does not specifically recognise prior indigenous Australian occupation and custodianship of the Australian shores will be something, I am sure, which will be offensive to many Australians and certainly to indigenous Australians.

The concluding points I would like to make are in the context of the purpose and nature of a referendum. It is commonly overlooked that section 128 of the Constitution, which prescribes how a referendum is conducted, provides that it is not the submitting of different options to the Australian people, it is actually the submission of a proposed law, passed by the parliament, to the Australian people. So those who suggest that there can be a canvassing of views of the Australian people as to what model of republic they want, are fundamentally mistaken. There will be a bill—which the government has put on the table—which will be passed by the parliament and that will be the question. That will be the only game in town, effectively, that voters should consider. So, with respect, some people are misleading the Australian public to say that they will have any broader options.

At the same time, it is important that Australians realise, as I have indicated, the significance of the bipartisan model of selection of the president. They should be reluctant to vote against the proposal or to conduct a spoiling action if they favour Australia becoming a republic.
Mrs Bronwyn Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am not sure that the minister at the table favours Australia becoming a republic, but those who intend to vote no—while still wanting Australia to become a republic—simply because they favour a direct election model, should think very carefully about those issues. They should think about what model they are proposing. Is it the United States model? Is it the Irish model? How do they intend to define the reserve powers that currently apply to the Attorney-General? All these things would have to be resolved before the Australian people could legitimately consider such a model. Such a model will not emanate from this House—the issues are too party political and it simply will not occur.

speech.para: So the only prospect of Australia becoming a republic is effectively this bipartisan model where there will be a non-politician selected by both houses of parliament. In other words, the referendum is not a dress rehearsal; there is no realistic opportunity to have another bite at the cherry in the foreseeable future.
Mrs Bronwyn Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The minister says, `Of course there is.' I am not sure how much of the Australian taxpayers' money she wants to spend on going around the world again. Last year's Constitutional Convention cost somewhere in the vicinity of $28 million; this bill will facilitate the expenditure of $19½ million; the referendum itself, later on this year, will cost some $55 million. So, if the minister is suggesting that any responsible government will lightly commit $100 million for a re-run of a similar referendum proposal in the near future, she—with respect—is ignorant of what the Australian people will tolerate in respect of the allocation of their funds. We say the expenditure which has occurred and which will occur is appropriate and, indeed, must be expended for a very historically significant event. But it is something that a government of any political persuasion would not lightly do again. So any person who argues that there can simply be a re-run of this referendum is deluding themselves and, worse still, is deluding the Australian people. This is certainly not a trial run; this is very much the real thing.

speech.para: We are approaching this matter from the point of view of cooperating with the government. We hope they will display more cooperation towards us in this process than was given to us in the preparation of the draft preamble. There is still time for us to work together to come up with a form of words that the Australian people can genuinely feel ownership of. If the government is serious and fair dinkum about the overview parliamentary committee that will look into these issues, then there is a possibility for a sensible and unifying outcome to take place.

Essentially, Australia has evolved from the time of Federation when we were still very much dependent on the United Kingdom. In this century, we have obtained our judicial and, indeed, our statutory independence—for instance, with the Statute of Westminster and the Australia Act of 1986. All these things have been very significant in our becoming an independent and sovereign nation. But the final step in that process is to obtain our own head of state who is an Australian—a position that any child born in this nation can aspire to. There is an opportunity for Australians to engage in that process later in the year. We will have an opportunity to have an Australian citizen as our head of state—an Australian citizen who is a non-politician—without any other changes to our structure of government which we cherish so dearly.
In summary, the opposition supports this bill and looks forward to a series of cooperative interchanges with the government on these very important and historically significant issues.

talk.start.para: —The Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 is designed to enable the Commonwealth to provide funding for public education campaigns about the forthcoming referendum. The bill also allows for the printing, publication and distribution of material relating to the yes and no case in the referendum. I understand that amendments are being moved which will allow the printing of the two referenda questions on separate ballot papers to minimise any confusion between the republic question and the preamble question. The bill also enables the AEC to more broadly distribute material relating to the referendum, including via the Internet.

speech.para: This bill is a further stage in the process the coalition committed itself to prior to the 1996 election. Last year, in accordance with the government's commitment to enter into a process to resolve the issue of a republic, the Constitutional Convention was held. The convention agreed in principle that Australia should become a republic. It also supported the bipartisan appointment of the president model being put to a national referendum.

Members of the House will recall that during last year's Constitutional Convention some delegates to the convention expressed concern, as did the member for Barton, about the level of understanding and awareness in the community about aspects of the constitutional reform process and our system of government. The government made a commitment that, prior to the referendum being put to the people, it would fund a public education campaign to assist the electorate in its understanding of the issues surrounding the referendum.

The amendments contained in this bill are necessary to ensure that this education process does not breach the provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 which limit expenditure on the presentation of material relating to a referendum to only the yes and no cases. These amendments will only apply to the November referendum. The government will provide some $4.5 million to be allocated to a public education program to be introduced soon after the referendum legislation enters parliament. The education program will predate the advertising campaign about the yes and no case, and it will seek to highlight general information about our system of government and the referendum.

The program will seek to increase understanding and awareness about the issues surrounding the referendum, including the bipartisan appointment of the president model; the current system of government to set the model in context; and the referendum process itself. In order to assist in this public education program and to promote interest in the referendum, the Commonwealth will be embarking on a series of information initiatives, including the free distribution of a plain English information kit and advertising campaign translated into up to 16 languages, which will provide information about the referendum proposal and how to access further information about it. There will be an Internet site and alternative information formats for those who, like some of us, are sight-impaired.

The purpose of this information program is not to promote either side of the referendum argument but instead to increase electorate awareness about the issues at hand. Research conducted by the Commonwealth indicates that whilst Australians have a significant level of knowledge about the Constitution and government there is room for improvement. In 1994 the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet commissioned ANOP research services to conduct research into the level of understanding and knowledge in the Australian community about government, constitutional and citizenship issues.

The study drew some conclusions which, while now five years old, still provide some insight into levels of community awareness of, interest in, and knowledge of aspects of our system of government. The study argued that there was significant work to be done in increasing public education about the Australian Constitution. And, not to put too fine a point on it, the ANOP study found that `there was a high level of ignorance about Australia's government'. For instance, some 18 per cent of the 2,500 individuals interviewed showed some degree of understanding of the Constitution while 12 per cent held misconceptions about what the Constitution covered. These points were made by my colleague the member for Barton in his speech. The study also revealed that on the issue of the republic there was a relatively low level of community knowledge. But these figures would no doubt be significantly higher today after the years of intensive debate and last year's Constitutional Convention.

But I also have to say—partly in response to the ANOP findings, partly in response to comments that are occasionally made by politicians and partly in response to the member for Barton's comments—that the conclusions about a high level of ignorance amongst the Australian public are, in my view, a little overstated. The ANOP survey, for instance, found:
Most people are familiar with the mechanics of voting, and have a fair understanding of the roles of the Commonwealth, State and Local Government.
