And it was clear from the research that the community did have a quite strong knowledge of the election processes and the federal parliament. At least 40 per cent could name both houses of parliament, and 41 per cent of interviewees understood the process of changing the Constitution.

And I have to say that, surprisingly, the study found it a deficiency in community knowledge that `only 24 per cent of people were aware that the Senate represented the states'. This is rather a curious conclusion given that, in fact, today the Senate is much more than simply a chamber representing the states. I have to say it is unusual in a survey which reflects the recognition that the Senate has moved well beyond what it was originally conceived of doing that it is somehow concluded that this reflects a lack of awareness amongst the community. I would have thought it reflected considerable perception. Of course, even a close student of politics can at times be forgiven for not knowing what the Senate stands for these days.

But my bottom line on this is that, although the electorate may have some difficulty understanding some aspects of the governmental process, we should not underestimate the strong degree of commonsense and political understanding that the Australian electorate holds. Only yesterday I had the opportunity to talk with a group of year 12 students from Siena College, and their level of political awareness and astuteness about politics surpassed what I have on occasions seen coming from the other side of the House. But it is unfortunate that some of us repeatedly underestimate the commonsense and political sophistication of the electorate.

However, it is correct that work remains to be done in terms of public education. Although an issue is in the news, it does not necessarily transfer into public awareness of the processes at hand. The public information campaign that will flow from these amendments will seek to assist in increasing awareness of the process without presenting the arguments for and against the proposed referendum options. This will, however, need a certain amount of judgment and sensitivity by the expert group that is appointed to prepare and vet the material for the campaign.

I was interested, for instance, that the member for Barton said it was very important that the dispassionate information provided at this stage of the campaign should show that there would be no change to the system at all. Indeed, one of the objectives the public information campaign is supposed to address—and I quote the Attorney-General—is balanced material on `the bipartisan appointment of the president model and the issues it raises'. I am afraid this may well be a daunting task, contrary to the comments of the member for Barton.

Let us for a moment take one of the issues raised by the `bipartisan appointment of the president' model. At first glance the proposal appears to simply be a replacement of the Queen's representative with an Australian president. But there is a real concern that the proposal could create a presidency combining the powers of the Governor-General with an unprecedented degree of parliamentary legitimacy and national authority. Elected by two-thirds of the Australian parliament, the president would have greater parliamentary endorsement than a Prime Minister, who needs only command majority support in the House of Representatives. The creation of a president with uncodified powers, parliamentary support and national authority could significantly alter the operation of our political system. Such a person could send the nation into constitutional crisis. David Solomon in his recent work Coming of age: charter for a new Australia graphically spells out the full extent of the problem. I quote:

If moving to a republic is simply going to involve substituting the word `President' for the words `Governor-General', the potential would exist for a future president to take control of most of the organs of government.

This is a rather different perspective from the perspective that the member for Barton is putting forward that the committee of experts should actively persuade people that there will be no real change. The difficulty for the expert committee lies in how far down the track they wish to pursue these issues in a public education campaign, and I have to say that I wish the expert committee well in their endeavours.

The bill also provides for the introduction of separate ballot papers on different coloured paper for each referendum proposal. I believe that this is a worthwhile initiative and it will undoubtedly help differentiate between different referendum questions. In the previous vein, however, I do not think we should forget that, since Federation, Australians have been able to successfully vote on a number of referendums on the same day, with voters being able to differentiate between different issues, despite the fact that they were all on one piece of paper. In particular, I have in mind the May 1977 referendum, when we had four questions and a national song poll. On that occasion, three referendum questions were successfully carried while the fourth, on simultaneous elections for the House and Senate, was not supported.

The bill also provides for the government's commitment to provide funds for a national advertising campaign that will accompany the yes and no cases for the referendum. The advertising campaigns are to be managed by government appointed committees, each of which will develop an advertising campaign for the yes and no case respectively. The committee for the yes case will include Malcolm Turnbull, Janet Holmes a Court, the Hon. Neville Wran, Jason Yat Sen Li and Chris Gallus, amongst others. The committee for the no case will include Kerry Jones, Senator Alan Ferguson, General `Digger' James, Senator Boswell, Dame Leonie Kramer and five others. This no case committee includes representatives of the position that stands for the direct election of the president, such as Clem Jones and Ted Mack. I have to say that the combination of monarchists and direct election proponents on the same committee should make the administration and decision making on the committee rather more interesting than usual.

Each committee will be allocated $7.5 million to develop advertisements and media promotion that will appear in the month preceding the campaign. The funds will be utilised for the preparation of advertising campaigns, including the retention of consultants in market research and advertising. The government will make available the assistance of the government communications unit. The two committees will not be able to receive additional private donations and apply them to run additional publicly funded advertisements.

The managers of the yes and no advertising campaigns do have substantial responsibilities. The government's vetting of these advertisements does not extend beyond ensuring the advertisements accord with acceptable levels of advertising, but a robust public debate still carries with it the responsibility for a full and frank airing of all the issues. I personally would encourage both the yes and no campaign managers and committees to remember that, whilst the issue of the republic is one of profound symbolic significance, it should not obscure the fact that substantial change will accompany movement from a constitutional monarchy to a republic.

Proponents of a minimalist republic oppose calls for the direct election of a president because they claim it would involve too great a constitutional change. What they do not admit is that their own model will fundamentally change the realities of the Constitution in Australia. It also has to be said that the minimalist republicans are not the only group that have not fully spelt out the real consequences of their position. Monarchists would have us believe that a successful no vote will mean a retention of the status quo and political continuity. But in fact this will only happen if a no vote is a genuine endorsement of the current system, rather than a protest vote against an unacceptable republican alternative.

I have already stated my view that it would have been desirable to hold an indicative poll, in conjunction with the referendum, to gauge what appears to be an overwhelming level of support in the community for the direct election proposal. The fact is that all the polls that have surfaced over the last five or six years, including the polls earlier this year, indicate that a majority of men and women, that live in country or city, whether they vote Liberal or Labor, have expressed a preference for directly electing a president. These sorts of things need to be thrashed out and the consequences of that do need looking at.

I have said before—and it remains my view—that, as things stand, there is a strong prospect of the referendum settling nothing and leaving a residue of division and disappointment. I am concerned that a majority no vote will leave unanswered the issue of whether or not the vote is a genuine affirmation of a constitutional monarchy or a protest vote by a majority of Australians who support a directly elected president but do not have the option of expressing this view. However, like monarchists and the minimalist republicans, proponents of a directly elected president also need to address the serious constitutional concerns that exist over the role and division of powers between the office of president and prime minister under a directly elected prospect. There is the prospect of alternative sources of authority and legitimacy being created and a directly elected president emerging as a politicised extension of our political parties.

Australia needs to deal with the issue of our head of state in a thoughtful and deliberate way. The advertisements and campaigns by both the yes and no cases should reflect this, rather than being negative attacks on one another's respective positions. I know that may sound pious coming from me, as someone who has conducted a number of campaigns that unkind people would have described as being negative—

talk.start.para: —Good to see you pleading guilty for a change.
—Mate, the guilty party is over that side.

speech.para: Mr Albanese interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You are all guilty. But what is important to emphasise is that this is not a partisan political campaign. The referendum debate is about the future of our Constitution. Since 1996 I have argued that it deserves a proper, open, free and honest hearing.
—He is respectable, now.

—I have always been respectable. It is not about winning at all costs. It is about what we set out to resolve—coming to a national consensus which reflects the informed wishes of the Australian people. Ultimately the Australian Constitution does belong to the Australian people and only they can—and only they should—decide what form of government we are to have. I think that this campaign and the education campaign should give them the opportunity to make a decision that is fully informed. I hope that the managers of both national advertising campaigns do take these views seriously in the coming public debate. I say once again that this process is as much about an honest, full and frank debate about Australia's future as it is about winning a vote. I commend the bill to the House.

—I rise to speak in support of the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill and in doing so I wish to respond to some of the comments made by the members opposite. The Labor Party is supporting this bill and we take a lot of pride in the fact that we have been at the forefront of the push for Australia to come to maturity as a republic. I well remember sitting in the audience of the 1993 ALP campaign launch where Paul Keating announced that the Labor Party policy would be to support Australia becoming a republic. That was a great moment. Once again it was the Australian Labor Party pushing Australia forward, showing vision, under the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating.
—Your friend.

—Indeed, my friend, with whom I am very proud to be associated. This bill today permits expenditure for both the yes and no campaign committees. These committees are to be drawn from a very broad cross-section of both supporters and opponents of the matter under decision in the upcoming referendum. Indeed, I will be making some comments later about the `no' campaign committee and the breadth of it.

speech.para: This bill also allows the AEC to spend money on wider than normal distribution of campaign material about exactly what this change means, which will be necessary for the education campaign to be conducted in the Australian electorate. I believe the education campaign will be particularly important, because the opponents of the republic rely upon fear and misinformation. Once people are made aware of exactly what the change means, then they will support it. Further, this bill contains provisions for some mechanical implementation of the referendum, such as allowing ballot papers to be different colours for two or more referenda on the same day, and corrects a provision which protects the secrecy of the voter's ballot.

I want to comment on why we should move to a republic. In 1999 I believe that it is entirely appropriate, as we look towards the new millennium, that we speak about what sort of country we see Australia being and where we want to go in the future. We have a unique cultural identity. As of the last census in 1996, 3.9 million Australian residents were born overseas. Many of these people certainly do not identify with the British monarch.

It is perhaps unfortunate that you have got to be over 18 to vote in this referendum, because it is very clear that the people who will be here longer than those of us in this chamber support moving to a republic. A Newspoll conducted from 29 to 31 January this year found that 60 per cent of 18- to 24-year-olds and 65.7 per cent of 25- to 34-year-olds are in favour of the model proposed by the Constitutional Convention.

We live in a world which, with globalisation, is increasingly becoming international, in which national boundaries are being over taken by the breadth and pace of technological change and in which the days when we looked towards Britain as the motherland are long, long gone.

I recall one of the first activities after I was elected was the visit of a statesman to this country, President Bill Clinton. I well remember the luncheon that was held in the Great Hall of Parliament House. I remember the groan from parliamentarians and civic leaders when, in response to the Prime Minister's toast to the President of the United States, President Clinton had to toast the Queen of Australia. I was sitting at a table with members of the coalition and they all groaned. They said, `Isn't it embarrassing?' Indeed it was embarrassing.

The model adopted by the Constitutional Convention which will go before the Australian people later this year is one which is entirely appropriate. It allows for the president to be nominated by any Australian. These nominations would then be vetted by a committee of the parliament. A short list would be given to the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister would move and the opposition leader second a single nomination to a joint sitting of both houses. It would require a two-thirds majority of both houses in order to get support. This model would ensure, more than any other model proposed, that a party political person or someone who is seen to be too partisan simply would not gain the support as envisaged in this model. So for those people who speak about politicians staying out of the debate and ensuring that we do not have a politician as our head of state, this is the model.

If you have a situation where there is a direct election, there is nothing more certain than that a candidate backed by either Labor or the coalition will become the head of state, the president. That would create a potential disaster in terms of conflicting powers between a president who may well feel a lot of pressure—given the support that he or she would be given by a major political party—to act in a partisan manner, potentially in opposition to the elected government of the day. That would be an un-Australian move and something that I will not support.

I want to make some comments about the direct election lobby. In his column in the Australian on 27 January, Ted Mack said, `The debate on an Australian republic has been too emotional and divisive.' This is typical of the patronising approach of those opposite who favour the direct election of a president. Why shouldn't the debate about a republic be emotional? The move to a republic is the most significant step in our history since Federation. Surely we should be pleased at the level of interest the debate has attracted. The greatest cause of divisiveness has been the prodirect election lobby. We now face a ludicrous situation where a group which claims to be in favour of a republic could well stop it ever happening. How disappointing this would be for many Australians who want a republic and who voted for candidates such as Ted Mack for the Constitutional Convention. Mack and his cronies were elected as a result of the groundswell of support for a republic. They were happy to attend the Constitutional Convention and participate in the debates, but once it became clear that they were not going to win majority support for their position they instantly set about undermining the whole process.

To make things worse, the pro-direct election lobby cannot even agree on a model for direct election. They would not agree on a model at the convention and now a year later they are still arguing about how a president could be directly elected. Ted Mack favours a US style presidency. Clem Jones wants a president with executive powers, while Phil Cleary wants an Irish style presidency. Without even knowing what they want, these people are prepared to do whatever it takes to see the upcoming referendum defeated.

They might argue that we will have another shot at a referendum. If they have not been able to agree on a model in the last 12 months—and we are talking about a fairly small group of people; there are not two of them who have the same position on the direct election model—you have to ask whether they will ever be able to agree on a referendum question, let alone get it carried. By opposing the model supported by the convention, Mack and his cronies are effec tively saying that it is better to have a foreign monarch as head of state than an Australian selected by the parliament. If they had been honest about this when standing for the Constitutional Convention, they would have had a lot of trouble finding support in the electorate.

This referendum is not the last word on our political system. There is nothing to stop us changing our model of republic in the future, but this referendum is the last chance this generation has of seeing an Australian head of state. Mack would have us hold a plebiscite and then another convention. Assuming that this collection of the extreme Right, the Trots and other assorted rabble could actually reach a position then, he would have us hold another referendum. If the upcoming referendum does not succeed, I would not be holding my breath.

This really exposes them with regard to their oppositionist politics. When people such as Phil Cleary and Ted Mack were here in parliament they were very good at saying what they were against; they are not so good at saying what they are for. The ultimate irony of this was the vision of Peter Reith going to see Ted Mack at his house on the North Shore of Sydney. There he was with his adviser going in. He did not take the balaclava. He tied up the dogs at the front doorstep of Ted Mack's substantial North Shore home. There we had Peter Reith slinking out trying to get a bit of publicity. All the TV cameras were there for this private meeting. He, of all people, said, `We want a directly elected president because I am the supporter of direct democracy.' This is the bloke who used mace, dogs and balaclavas, which will forever be associated with him after the Maritime Union dispute. If people like Ted Mack or Phil Cleary or others want to associate with him, then I say so be it. They expose the frauds that they are.

I also want to raise today the Prime Minister's preferred preamble which, after a discussion in the coalition party room yesterday, has been released. It shows the confusion, the contradiction and the incompetence which run through the government's response to anything to do with the republic. The preamble is not about the future of the nation; it is about John Howard's past—the white picket fences, Anglo-Celtic suburbs, 2.2 children, the idea of a homogenous society in which all citizens are just like the current Prime Minister. This of course was never the reality, not in the 1950s and certainly not now. The proposed draft preamble states:
. . . the Commonwealth of Australia is constituted by the equal sovereignty of all its citizens.

But it goes no further than recognising Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as having `inhabited' the land before European invasion. Big deal! The Prime Minister acknowledges that there were people here before 1788. He does not go further than that because he is not capable of making that step forward. How can we have equal sovereignty if the oldest form of sovereignty in Australia, the sovereignty of indigenous peoples over the land, is denied? It also says:

Australia's democratic and federal system of government exists under law to preserve and protect all Australians in an equal dignity which may never be infringed by prejudice or fashion or ideology . . .

What hypocrisy! The government, on the one hand, wants to deny the reality of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history and dispossession but, on the other hand, is quite happy to turn around and claim to believe in a system free of prejudice. This is typical of the arrogant approach of this government.

Only several days after being found guilty of racial discrimination by the UN Committee on Racial Discrimination, the Prime Minister wants to take his agenda even further. It was not enough to eliminate the legal property rights of indigenous people. He wants to make doubly sure by enshrining a rose-coloured glasses view of history in the Constitution. There is nothing about the custodianship that indigenous people had over this country for some 40,000 years. As a country we have an unfortunate history of concealing and denying our past. It is only in the last few decades that school students have started to learn the truth about indigenous culture and history. But the Prime Minister wants to take a giant leap backwards by using the Constitution, the most important document in the Australian legal system, to entrench his own distorted view of our past.

The preamble also reflects the plain old dullness and lack of vision of this Prime Minister. He says we should be free to be proud of our country. Who suggests we are not? That is one reason I am proud to be a republican, because I am proud to live in Australia and I do not believe that Australia should have to genuflect before a foreign power. It is one thing to live in the past. The problem with this Prime Minister is that he wants us all to stay back to keep him company. He just cannot make that leap forward. He is not content with being the leader of the only Western government ever to be found guilty of racial discrimination by the UN. He wants to build on this record. The Prime Minister then includes in the preamble to the Constitution a statement about mateship. It really is desperate. You can imagine him sitting around in the 1950s—

talk.start.para: —Andrew Peacock wrote that.

—I am told by the member for Batman that Andrew Peacock wrote that, and we know that Andrew Peacock and John Howard were indeed great mates. If there is one thing that John Howard knows about, it is mateship. Given their different positions on the republic, perhaps it came out of a debate between Peter Costello and Peter Reith about mateship, because we can learn a lot from them. The draft of the preamble that has been put forward is simply not good enough. We believe that it must go to the joint select committee for reworking. There should be input from non-politicians drawn from the Constitutional Convention. If you want to look at which party stands for the future and which party stands for the past, the comparison with the proposed preamble circulated by the Leader of the Opposition really highlights that difference.

speech.para: The Olympics have also thrown the spotlight on the need for change. By rights, the games should be opened by our head of state—that is, the Queen. Despite the Prime Minister's open support for the monarchy, he wants to break with this tradition. Whether the games are opened by Mr Howard or the Queen, we are left in a pretty embarrassing position. If it is the Queen, we have to explain not only why we have the Union Jack on the corner of our flag but also why our head of state is a foreign monarch. If it is Mr Howard, we have to explain why we have to break with tradition and have the games opened by somebody other than our head of state. The former Prime Minister Paul Keating was criticised by the British press for placing his hand on the back of the Queen.

talk.start.para: —They've got more to criticise him for now.

—The minister at the table will remember that. I am sure that she was part of it. This Prime Minister has gone a substantial step forward. He has not put his hand on the back of the Queen; he has shoved her aside. He has pushed her aside in the rush so that he can open the Olympics.
—The member for Grayndler, I think we might just stick to the bill.

—I am speaking about the republic, Madam Deputy Speaker, which this bill is certainly about. Perhaps if people stopped interjecting it would be a lot easier. The fact is that, in the year 2000, as the thoughts of the world are on the new millennium, the Australia the Prime Minister would have the world see is an Australia of the past, an Australia which is subservient to Britain, an Australia which is too immature for its own head of state, and an Australia which persists in denying the reality of indigenous history. The republic referendum is our one great chance to change all of this, and we should not let this opportunity pass.

—While some people on the left will have enjoyed the speech of the member for Grayndler, unfortunately he did not really touch on the bill at hand, the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . He spent most of his contribution talking about the republic and the preamble and making loose personal attacks on the Prime Minister and others. But, in fact, this bill is not about the republic and the preamble; it is simply the machinery bill to set up the mechanisms for the referendum to be held in November this year.

speech.para: On the question of the preamble, I would have thought that the Labor Party would have been delighted with the wording of the preamble put forward by the Prime Minister and its inclusion of immigration and immigrants, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage as part of our Australian heritage and, indeed, the cultural heritage of people from all migrant backgrounds and indigenous backgrounds. It is a fair preamble. I hope it will get the support of the minor parties in the Senate and hopefully of the Labor Party by the time it gets to that point so it can be passed and put successfully in the referendum at the end of this year.

It does surprise me that the member for Grayndler would be opposed to putting `mateship' in a preamble, given the egalitarian pretensions of the Labor Party in the last 100 years. I would have thought they would have been very supportive of mateship being included in the preamble. They do hold themselves out to be the great egalitarian party. We know that is not true. Any cursory look at the trade union movement will show that women have never been given the opportunity for promotion in the trade union movement.

talk.start.para: —Just look at the president, you dope!
—Member for Grayndler, that sort of language is not acceptable in the House.
—What about the language he was using?
—I would ask the member for Grayndler to withdraw.
—I would ask you to withdraw your personal reference to the member for Sturt.
—Yes, I am most offended, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—I want you to withdraw your comment about the member for Sturt.
—I was shocked by that epithet being flung across the chamber at me.
—Resume your seat, Member for Sturt. Member for Grayndler, I want you to withdraw your personal comment about the member for Sturt.
—I withdraw if I offended the member by calling him a dope.
—If that is the best the member can do, you will have to resume, Member for Sturt.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I noted the unhappy means by which the member for Grayndler withdrew the nasty epithet he flung at me across the chamber. But I have come to expect this from the member for Grayndler, who does seem to run a business in personal attacks on members of this side. I refer to his speech last year that was a very vicious personal attack on the Prime Minister.

speech.para: I was also surprised to hear the member for Grayndler commenting about Paul Keating and his role. After the 60 Minutes show on Sunday night, I would have thought the Labor Party would have been running a mile from referring to Mr Keating and his role.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order, under standing order 145, on relevance to the bill.
—No, that is for questions.

—With respect, the chair will decide that. There has been a wide-ranging discussion of which the member for Grayndler was part, with respect, and the member for Sturt is equally wide ranging in his address to the bill.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I would point out to the member for Grayndler that, in fact, standing order 145 is about question time. There is a standing order that deals with relevance to the bill. But, given the member for Grayndler's contribution to this debate, he is in no position to be standing up and requiring people to refer to the purpose of this bill.

speech.para: I was surprised to see those opposite talking about the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, after the 60 Minutes show on Sunday night. I watched it, and I was shocked to see the allegations made against a former member of this House. I hope that in the course of time they will be properly tested.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It goes to a question of relevance.
—No, we have discussed that.

—No, I will ask to be heard out. The 60 Minutes program is about as relevant as the Prime Minister's commissions from Clayton Utz, the details of which—as to who paid them and for what purposes they were paid—he has refused to fully disclose to the House.

—Member for Batman, we have discussed the matter of relevance. The member for Grayndler has raised it. We have settled it. It has been a wide-ranging debate. There has been a lot of leniency from the chair towards members on the other side, and that will continue during this debate.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I do not want to prolong the discussion of Mr Keating and the 60 Minutes show. But, with respect to relevance, I would comment that the member for Grayndler was talking about shoving the Queen aside for the Olympics, which hardly had any bearing at all on this bill. I was disappointed that he did not bring himself to the bill at all. But I will now do so, because I think it is important that somebody in this debate actually talks about the bill at hand.

speech.para: The Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999, presently before the House, provides for amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 for the purposes of holding a referendum on a republic and the preamble scheduled to be conducted later this year. This bill effectively delivers on another coalition election promise. Before the 1996 federal election, the coalition proposed to hold a Constitutional Convention to explore the constitutional options available to Australia and, in particular, to find out whether we as a nation wanted to embrace the important symbolism of a change to an Australian head of state.

It has been clear for many years that a significant and increasing number of Australians from all walks of life support the idea of an Australian head of state. But it is also true that many Australians feel there is no compelling reason to abandon a system which has overseen one of the most stable democracies of the 21st century.

Despite years of talk from a former Labor government, it fell to a coalition government to make the convention a reality and an Australian head of state a democratic possibility. The convention was established to consider three questions: whether or not Australia should become a republic; which republic model should be put to the voters to consider against the current system of government; and in what time frame and under what circumstances any change might be considered.

The Constitutional Convention brought together a broad and representative cross-section of the Australian community. Opinions were regularly divided. But the debate was robust and constructive, this being due in no small part to the tireless efforts of the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair and the Hon. Barry Jones, who presided as chairman and deputy chairman respectively.

Half of the convention's 152 delegates were appointed by the government and represented a broad cross-section of Australian society and a wide diversity of skills and experience. They also reflected the government's commitment to ensuring that women, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, young Australians and local government were represented. The government resolved that the other 76 delegates should be elected by the Australian public. Just over 600 Australians offered themselves for candidature. The elected delegates made a profound contribution to the debate, which reflected very positively on the strength and character of Australia's democracy.

From the early stages of the convention it was quite clear that, although there was a healthy representation of delegates who supported the status quo, there was an overwhelming level of support for an Australian head of state. The real debate was about what model Australia should adopt to achieve that end.

The model which colloquially became known as `direct election' failed to achieve the same level of support at the convention as it has publicly. Indeed, the direct election model is the greatest danger the Constitution has faced. Although it enjoys considerable popular appeal, the flaws of the direct election model become plainly apparent under closer scrutiny.

Under the direct election model, the position of president would be a political prize which is constitutionally more powerful than the office of the Prime Minister. It is inevitable that a political party would enter a candidate and use its resources and experience in a campaign for president. It also contains severe disadvantages for the smaller states taking account of their population sizes. New South Wales and Victoria, by sheer dint of population size, would naturally dominate the choice of person for president under a direct election model.

Of all the models considered by the convention, the `bipartisan appointment of the president' model had the most support in the final ballot. The convention voted in favour of a motion that a referendum be held to test that model against the existing system. The convention further recommended that, if the 1999 referendum results in support for an Australian head of state, the republic should come into effect by 1 January 2001. Whatever the outcome, the result of the referendum will be a decision that will be owned by all Australians.

The convention further recommended that, prior to the referendum being put to the people, the government should facilitate a public education program to address constitutional and other issues relevant to the referendum. Governments have a duty to make material available to the electorate which involves any significant change which is either proposed or legislated for, whether it be announcing initiatives such as private health insurance rebates, tax reform or constitutional change. Accordingly, the coalition government has indicated that it will support public information activities in relation to the referendum.

The government has made it clear that the question about Australia's head of state is one for the Australian people to decide. In order to make an informed decision, the Australian people must have access to relevant information about our system of government and the proposals for change. The public information activities associated with a referendum will involve three distinct stages. The first stage is expected to coincide with the consideration of the referendum legislation in the parliament and will consist of wide distribution of a `plain English' public education kit. The kit will principally explain in appropriate detail the existing system of government and the Constitutional Convention's preferred model for an Australian head of state. Information concerning the referendum process will also be included.

The availability of the kit will be promoted by an advertising campaign. Acknowledging Australia's great cultural diversity, the information kit will be available in other formats tailored to meet the requirements of particular audiences, including translations in 16 languages on the Internet and in alternative formats for the sight impaired. I am sure the minister at the dispatch box, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, will be delighted that the government's public education campaign will be translated in 16 languages so that Australians of multicultural backgrounds will be able to access that information.

The second stage, or the campaign phase, will occur in the three- to four-week period leading to the referendum ballot day. The government will make $15 million available for nationwide education campaigns to promote the arguments both for and against the model put forward in the referendum. The government has appointed two separate committees to manage the for and against campaigns. Recognising individual skills, demonstrated commitment and experience, the government has ensured that the membership of both committees are drawn from delegates to the Constitutional Convention.

Consistent with the government's approach to the debate about Australia's head of state, membership of the committees include a broadly representative cross-section of the community and is not confined to politicians. Community participation is essential to give the debate and referendum legitimacy. As such, the government has resolved that each committee will be responsible for the planning of its own campaign and will manage a budget of up to $7½ million. The committees will also have the freedom to develop advertisements which can be run through advertising mediums of their choice in the three to four weeks before the referendum. The government's only involvement in this process will be to ensure that proposed advertisements do not breach statutory requirements or accepted standards of advertising.

Public funding for the committees will lend itself to robust public debate on the arguments for and against change. As with the provision of public funding in election campaigns, the purpose is to ensure that alternative views can be presented directly to the voters. Once the legislation for altering the Constitution has been passed by both houses of parliament, the Australian Electoral Commission will have the responsibility for the conduct of the remainder of the referendum process. Therefore, the third stage of the process will be the responsibility of the AEC. This will include the public information activities, the actual distribution of the official yes and no campaign cases to all voters, as provided for by the provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984.

There are various sections of the act which will be amended by this bill. These amendments are generally mechanical in nature. However, the operation of subsection 4 inserted in what became section 11 of the act by means of an amendment in the Senate at the time of the passage of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Bill 1984 deserves special comment. The subsection arose out of a legitimate concern to create a statutory prohibition against any government funding partisan involvement in referendum campaigns. More specifically, the amendment was to avoid a situation where a government only supported one side of a question put to the electorate. Freedom of speech is a fundamental right, but it does not automatically follow that freedom of speech has to be funded by taxpayers through the Commonwealth. However, in the case of referendums, there is a strong argument that in the interests of fairness and active democracy the Commonwealth should make equal funds available to both sides of the argument.

The Australian public expects and demands this sort of fairness. Accordingly, clause 4 of the bill is not an attempt on the part of the government to tip the balance of the debate in favour of either side. Furthermore, clause 4 is intended to guarantee through legislative means that Commonwealth expenditure throughout the course of the government's three-stage program of public information activities for the 1999 referendum does not inadvertently result in a technical breach of subsection 11(4) of the relevant act. The amendments demonstrate that the coalition government is committed to presenting the Australian electorate with a fair and easy to follow account of the central issues surrounding the debate as well as a working knowledge and understanding of the arguments both for and against constitutional change.

The importance of this referendum in terms of Australia's international identity in the 21st century cannot be underestimated. The debate about an Australian head of state deserves the collective and undivided attention of our national leaders and the public. But at the moment that is not possible. Before the nation can afford to turn its attention to the debate about Australia's head of state, we must complete the tax reform process, the other great national opportunity in 1999. Australians paid dearly for Paul Keating's dogmatic pursuit of big picture items at the expense of getting the economic fundamentals right. Whether it was a lacerating recession or a recession we had to have is barely the point. The important lesson from this unhappy era is that Australians want a strong, confident economy as a starting point for good social policy, including constitutional reform.

The coalition government has returned the budget to a surplus from a $10 billion deficit and has cushioned the economy from the impact of the Asian financial crisis while delivering record low inflation and interest rates. The debate about an Australian head of state is important in terms of how we think about ourselves, but tax reform will have far more tangible benefits to ordinary Australians, and this process needs to be completed before we can legitimately move on. Tax reform will allow more families to enjoy high standards of living, will secure a revenue base to provide hospitals for the sick and benefits for the elderly and will gave salary and wage earners much needed tax relief. Tax reform will remove the shackles preventing small businesses and exporters from expanding and creating more jobs, and tax reform will improve Commonwealth-state financial relations.

Tax reform and the chance to change important symbols in our Constitution are the two great opportunities for Australia before the next millennium. The Australian electorate voted in favour of the government's tax reform plan at the last election. The people have spoken and the debate is finished. It is time to complete the tax reform process and then turn our energies and attention to the debate about an Australian head of state. That process will happen in the second half of the year. I commend this bill to the House in terms of the machinery provisions contained in it that will allow that referendum to continue and will also allow the preamble to be put in that referendum in November.

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . This bill exists because of one fact and one fact alone, and that is that one party in this parliament seven years ago put this proposal before the Australian nation—the proposal for an Australian republic. After years of sustained resistance by those opposite and by other groups in the Australian community, this government has finally yielded. We held a Constitutional Convention and we now have a decision based on the outcome of that Constitutional Convention to proceed to a referendum.

speech.para: The bill sets out a range of procedures and provisions. First, it establishes a process for the distribution by the Australian Electoral Commission of the yes/no cases to be put in association with the referendum—questions concerning that of an Australian republic and questions now also concerning that of an Australian preamble. Second, it deals with the provision of separate ballot papers for separate referendum questions. The bill also deals with other minor provisions concerning voting places. But the key provisions of this proposed legislation concern the question about an Australian republic, the funding of the yes/no case concerning that question as well as touching on, in part, the additional proposal for a new preamble to the Australian Constitution. The Attorney-General's second reading speech on this proposed legislation is quite instructive. He states:

The government has made it clear that the republic question is one for the Australian people to decide. In order to make an informed decision, the Australian people must have access to relevant information about our system of government and the proposal for change. The government believes that public funding should be made available to support a vigorous and engaging public presentation of the arguments for and against change.

Its essence is that there should be a free, fair and open debate on whether or not there should be an Australian republic. But that, in turn, assumes that there will be a debate. Here I refer to not only a debate between the Australian Republican Movement and Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy but also a debate between we the elected representatives of the people.

What we have found, however, is that this debate is a one-sided one. In terms of the party opposite, we find there are no active participants by those who claim on the one hand to support the republican cause but on the other hand are strangely silent in the public discussion of that cause. The silence has become increasingly deafening.
Our case—that of the parliamentary Labor Party—is very simple: we support an Australian republic; we support an Australian head of state; we support a new republic for a new century.

But where is the case being advanced by those opposite? We turn first to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister's view is locked in a different period. In his view of this nation, the Prime Minister is locked into the echoes of Land of Hope and Glory, Winston Churchill's portrait on the mantelpiece, Menzies still in the Lodge, cricket at Lords and chaps being chaps. It is a view of the future of Australia rooted firmly in 1954, the Royal Visit and `I did but see her passing by'. That is one view. It is a view which the Prime Minister is entitled to have. It is also the view of others within his party, including Senator Minchin, the great friend and colleague of the just now departed member for Sturt, not to mention the Minister for Employment Services, Mr Abbott, and the Minister for Aged Care, Mrs Bishop.

When we turn to the Liberal Party and ask, `Where are the republican participants in this debate?' we find very few taking up the public cause. Most importantly, we ask the question: where still is the Treasurer of the Commonwealth on this question; where is Mr Costello? Mr Costello, the Treasurer, is the senior ranking republican on the other side of this chamber, but when it comes to the substantial public debate on this issue he is missing in action.

The Treasurer was a participant in the Constitutional Convention last year. He emerged from that convention as a public advocate of the so-called McGarvie model for the republic—a puzzling model at best, but one which was far too patrician and elitist for most people supporting any form of republicanism in this country. After the Constitutional Convention the Treasurer, when asked whether he would be supporting the public debate and advocacy of a republic in the lead-up in any referendum, said, `Yes, but the model would have to be improved.' Well we might ask: how could a model which had been agreed upon by an exhaustive process of consultation involving a Constitutional Convention of many delegates across this country be improved? But that was his public position and the basis on which he justified a sustained silence in this debate over a long time.

We then had a comment from the Treasurer, `Even if this republican referendum goes down, what's the difference between the year 2000 and the year 2010? There is always a second time.' I often wonder, if that logic was applied in the great Federation debates of the 1890s, what would have been the response then had Deakin turned to Griffith and Griffith turned to Forrest and said, `Well, you know, 1901 seems as though it's not going to work, why don't we aim for 1911?' The bottom line is that it would never have happened. It is a false, unfortunate and unhelpful line of logic.

But, lo and behold, in the noble tradition of St Augustine, we had a conversion on 4 March, because the Australian of that day reports that the Treasurer, Peter Costello, the highest-ranking declared republican in the Howard Government, has warned Australians there will be no second chance for a republic if the November referendum fails. That sits at some point of contrast with his earlier remark, `What's 10 years between friends? We will get around to the republic at some stage.'

The bottom line is that here we are months away from this seminal referendum on the future of this nation's constitutional arrangements, yet we still have at best one public utterance from the Treasurer of the Commonwealth—the senior ranking republican from the party of those opposite—and not a sustained participation in the public discussion. We do not have a sustained argument to bring the constituency represented by those opposite along in support of the overall rationale for an Australian republic. So much for Citizen Costello.

We then turn to the other great republican on the other side—Citizen Reith. Citizen Reith's entry in this debate was dramatic to say the least. In January this year, as most of us were enjoying the summer slumber, Citizen Reith suddenly emerged on the doorstep of Ted Mack's house in Sydney, surprisingly with 15 television cameras in tow, to announce to all concerned that in fact he, Citizen Reith, had decided to become a direct election republican. I can only conclude that the reason for Mr Reith's sudden intervention in this debate and the dramatic way in which he did it was to so confuse the issue as to leave the entire Australian nation wondering where the conservative side of politics lay on this issue.

After all, we had Citizen Costello, the Treasurer of the Commonwealth, saying on the one hand that he was a McGarvieite, that he might get around to supporting the republic at some stage if his workload did not get in the road, and then we had the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, saying that in fact he is not an appointed presidency man at all, that he is not a McGarvieite but he is a direct election model person, siding with Mr Mack in that overall debate. The overall effect of that on the Australian community in this debate has been to leave an atmosphere of confusion and concern as to what precisely republicans on the benches opposite stand for.

What do we make in overall terms of these dog in the manger type tactics? It is difficult to reach a conclusion. We have even had statements from the government whip suggesting that those opposite should remain publicly silent in the republican debate, but that is an injunction—or a warning, shall we say—issued by the government whip which seems to be regularly ignored by the constitutional monarchists opposite. It does not seem to have stopped Senator Minchin in his stride nor Mr Abbott or Mrs Bishop in their stride.

We also had advice from Mr Robb, the former federal director of the Liberal Party, saying that he was concerned that voters would suffer from some form of fatigue if in fact we allowed politicians to participate in the public discussion on the republic too early. I would suggest that what we are facing at the moment is not voter fatigue but the absence of any form of debate at all. It is not fatigue. We have not even worked up a sweat yet. The reason we have not worked up a sweat yet is we do not have an engagement from those opposite who state they wish to see an Australian republic.

I return to the theme outlined in the summary of the bill which is that, for Australians to make a decision about the future of their constitutional arrangements in this year's referendum, there must be a debate. But this requires engagement. To date there has been no engagement. We have, in effect, the sound of one hand clapping, and the hand that is missing from this clapping, the hand that is missing from this engagement, is that of the Liberal Party. They are missing entirely from the fray. I fear that, if this referendum goes down, history will record that considerable culpability lies with those opposite for having, frankly, wimped it. We all know the constitutional history of this country. Out of the 42 referenda since Federation, eight have passed. All those which have passed have passed only on the basis of some form of bipartisan support.
The other matter of substance touched on in the bill before us concerns the preamble. I note in the minister's second reading speech that:

The government's commitment is to undertake a public education program directed to the republic proposal and to fund campaigns on that proposal. That commitment does not extend to the preamble proposal.

In essence, I fear that, in addition, we have a preamble designed to confuse. The preamble which has been circulated today by the Prime Minister has three fundamental flaws in it. The first is that its effect on those Australians who will vote in the referendum on the republic later this year is confusion. There will be two questions put, not one. Given the history of referenda in this country, when you complicate the referendum process, logic inevitably follows that the prospects of the case getting up are radically diminished. The second flaw relates to the substance of the preamble which has been advanced and the third relates to the style of that document.

As to its capacity to confuse the Australian electorate, my fear is that, in the midst of being confronted with the inevitable hurly-burly of the arguments raised by the Australian Republican Movement on the one hand and by Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy on the other, we will have injected a further level of controversy concerning the contents of this proposed preamble. The impact of that, whether it is by design or by accident—and I fear it is, in part, by design—will be to confuse and to lead ultimately to the defeat of the republican question.

I do not intend to dwell on the flaws of substance at any length other than to say that the single guiding document we have in this exercise on the republic is in fact the resolution which emerged from the Constitutional Convention of early last year. That convention outlined a range of specific provisions which were to be reflected in the future preamble to the Australian Constitution. The simple test which this document circulated by the Prime Minister must pass in terms of substance is whether it contains elements which reflect each of those agreed upon by the Constitutional Convention. I submit that they do not.

When we turn to the style of this document which has been circulated by the Prime Minister or his office today, I fear again we have something which is very poorly drafted indeed. In terms of a document which is supposed to inspire our national political consciousness, I fear this is woefully inadequate drafting. I would submit that, if this document which has been put about today is poetry, the Australian Yellow Pages represents a high form of literature worthy of a Nobel Prize.

This preamble does not flow. Its language is disjointed. It is entirely without rhythm. It is also without logic. It refers, for example, to the equal sovereignty of its citizens. In international law, sovereignty is a concept relating to the position of states, not of individuals. It refers to things like `arrivals' as persons who have come to this country from other countries. In my mind, `arrivals' refers to the thing which happens at a railway station. It is not a broader sweeping statement involving the millions of Australians—in fact, all of us who are non-indigenous—who have come here from other parts of the world.

The preamble says we should be `free to be proud'. I find that language silly. We are proud of this country irrespective of whether we are free. These are in fact quite different concepts. It refers to `an equal dignity'. Again, I do not find that concept even alive in any form of English language. The last paragraph of the circulated draft I find completely unintelligible. There is a need, as the member for Holt has said, for brevity, for poetry and for a capacity readily to commit this seminal document to the Australian memory, which means to the memory of its citizens. What we have before us is a draft which fails each of those tests.

Finally on this preamble question, we have flaws of process. I would simply make this point without dwelling on it further: to pull together a draft which actually summarises the past of this country and infuses us with a vision for its future must, by its definition, be done in a consultative fashion. Instead, what we have had is something dumped on the table in a draft that ignores that which has been circulated already by the Leader of the Opposition almost on every account.

The ultimate question alive in this entire debate on the republic is: why are we doing it anyway? What are the arguments for an Australian republic as opposed to those for an Australian constitutional monarchy? I think it is important in this important year that we remind ourselves of what we are about and why. What we want simply is an Australian head of state. What we do not want is a representative of the House of Hanover, the House of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, the House of Windsor or whoever that House happens to be at any particular time. What we do not want as a head of state is a foreigner. What we do not want as a head of state is someone for whom it is already predetermined must be the oldest male member of a particular family. What we do not want for this country as a head of state is someone who it is already predetermined must be an adherent of a particular branch of the Christian faith. What we want very simply is for our head of state to be an Australian. What we want very simply is for our head of state to be one of us, a person chosen by this parliament on the basis of merit, irrespective of their gender, irrespective of their background, irrespective of their religion.

Returning to the bill and concluding on this point, what we have had in this debate up until now is, I think, a confusion of process. What we have had is an absence of bipartisan support. What we have had in fact is a Liberal Party whose participation in support of the republican cause has at best been lukewarm and, frankly, I believe, cynical in the extreme. We have had the beginnings of the emergence of evidence of the same in relation to the proposed new preamble for the Constitution.

If we were to reflect back on the debates which occurred 100 years ago as this nation and its six constituent colonies debated whether or not we should become an Australian Federation, for the statesmen of that time, the challenge would have seemed as large as the one which we confront today. It was no easy thing. These were difficult and hard questions of policy. They went to the heart of people's sense of identity and where they belonged. The participants in that debate actually seized the opportunity and went forward. As Alfred Deakin said in his 1898 lecture:

The number actually against us is probably greater than ever: the timorous and passive will be induced to fall away; the forces against us are arrayed under capable chiefs. But few as we may be and weak by comparison, it will be greater glory, whether we succeed or fail. These are times that try men's souls.

Deakin two years before Federation. Deakin leading an argument in support of the future of this nation, not the past. The challenge for those opposite is to seize hold of Deakin's spirit for a new century. Deakin was one of yours. He was a Liberal. He was a Melbourne Liberal. He was a Victorian Liberal. But he was a person who held in his mind and in his heart the future of this nation rather than clinging to its past.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak tonight on the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . There are a couple of things I would like to talk about tonight, and the first one is that we must not confuse this issue we are talking about—that is, the enabling legislation—with the case itself. Later this year, in eight months time, we are going to have to confront that.

speech.para: What we are doing here is looking at what the government promised in its 1996 election commitment. The first part of the promise was to give Australians a representative Constitutional Convention and, having fulfilled that promise in February 1998, the second part of the promise was that, if a clear view emerged from that convention, it would be put to the Australian people by way of a referendum to decide whether or not we would become a republic. Nothing could be clearer than that. I suppose tonight in this debate we will all allow our own prejudices to roll out in respect of the core issue and the preamble, but we should not lose sight of the fact that what we are debating tonight is the fulfilment of the Howard-Fischer government's promise to put this matter before the Australian people.

What followed from the convention, and what is the third part of the commitment, is that the question we would put to the Australian people would mirror the intentions of the Constitutional Convention. Some of us are in favour of that and some of us are very clearly against it. Nevertheless, the legislation sets up the framework for this to happen. As a part of that, a seminal issue at the Constitutional Convention was the proposed method of electing a president. Most favoured the two-thirds model, that being a nomination by the Prime Minister which is seconded by the Leader of the Opposition and put to a joint sitting of both houses of parliament, requiring a two-thirds majority to elect the president. This then is the fulfilment of the consequence of those earlier pledges.

As we are now well aware, a second issue emerged from the Constitutional Convention, and that was the need for a preamble to our Constitution. Perhaps it is appropriate that we are debating this issue today, on the day that the Prime Minister released the draft of that preamble. The Prime Minister put it very succinctly when he said this morning that the government's intention was to express in contemporary terms and essentially in an ageless language some of the historical realities of our country, our contemporary values and some of the things we hold dear.

You cannot have a preamble that, like the litany of the saints, just goes on and on. Somewhere you have to say what your core values are, what things you hold dear and what the aspirations of your country are.

We are talking today about the legislation which will allow this to happen and not where we stand on the yes or no cases on the issue. That will be put at the time of the referendum itself. I have a great concern about this because it has been traditional in the past in Australian referenda to place a number of issues before the public on one ballot paper. I have always thought that that was a grave mistake. I personally do not favour it because, in the past, there has been a tendency to vote yes if you are broadly in favour of the issues that the government is putting in the referendum or, if you are against them, to vote no.

I cite as evidence of that the results of the 3 September 1988 referendum, which you will recall was in four parts. We talked about four constitutional alterations: one regarding parliamentary terms, one regarding fair elections, one regarding the status of local government and one regarding rights and freedoms. You might say, on the face of it, that at least two of those issues were fairly passive ones. Certainly, there has been a view around—and it has been mirrored in a number of the states—that we have probably reached a stage where four-year terms are appropriate. Yet, in the context of that referendum, the public almost exclusively—there may have been just one exception—voted no to every issue in every state and territory.

It is remarkable, when you look at the figures, that the degree by which they voted down each issue roughly mirrors each issue itself in each state. For example, in New South Wales it was a bit over two to one against the parliamentary terms, not quite as much for fair elections, but back again to over two to one for the local government issue and more than two to one for the rights and freedoms. You can take any state at random and you will get this proportionality running through all the issues. That says to me that people's ambivalence with the government of the day or what they see as the government's intent has largely coloured the way they voted. And if you overlay that with the tendency generally to be cautious and vote no, it was quite remarkable that, in those four referenda, there was a majority of three million against on each issue in addition to all the states and territories voting the thing down.

We are not talking this time about some tinkering at the edges or tidying up the Constitution; we are talking in this instance about a fundamental change to the way we are governed. Some might say it is not that big a change—I think it is. We are changing from a monarchical system to a republican system, if the referendum is carried, and you cannot escape the implications of that, whether you are for it or against it. It is a very clear issue.

Then we have the issue of a preamble. As we go into the second millennium, as we go into our second century of the Commonwealth, a preamble might sit in front of the existing Constitution—even in its monarchist form—as well as it might sit in front of a republican form. So, to me, the issues are quite different and I thought it would be a great pity to put those on the one ballot paper. For that reason, I initiated a move within various forums of the coalition to consider two ballot papers, perhaps two slightly different coloured—a pink and a blue ballot paper.

talk.start.para: —Pink for the republic?

—I hope not, Gareth. It is important not only that we have to vote yes or no on these issues but that we confront them separately. There are four possible results out of these two referendums. We could get two yeses, two noes, a no and a yes, or a yes and a no. If we got those in the wrong combination, that would be the worst of all worlds, would it not? It would be a tragedy if we were perhaps to vote down a statement of the character and aspirations of our country because the referendum issue itself was defeated in four of the states. So I put it to the government—and I am delighted that they have accepted my suggestion—that we should vote in this election on two different ballot papers.

speech.para: Having said that, I want to make it clear that I do not necessarily support the republic. What I am supporting in this bill tonight is the right of people to vote on that issue, as I said earlier in my address, in the terms that the government promised back in 1996 and gave life to in the Constitutional Convention of 1998. My personal view is that we must look very seriously at this preamble issue. There will no doubt be a lot of criticism of particular issues, but I would appeal to people to look for the common ground in this pre amble rather than push the envelope to the extremities of various arguments, because—and I say this with the greatest sincerity—if we cannot agree on something as fundamental as the character and aspirations of this country in a simple preamble to our Constitution at this crucial time in our national development, be it in a monarchist or republican form—that is not important—then we are certainly ill-equipped to consider the issue of changing the form of government.

I think this first draft is a very good attempt to try to take all the features of our character on board. I do not think you can take every single feature of our character and aspirations into a preamble. What I do like about it is that it is not an extremist document; it is not overcolourful. I think it reflects what most Australians tend to do in their own lives—understate our situation a little. I think that reflects our character. What I particularly like about it is that it does not pander to political correctness. Political correctness is a fad we are going through now. It may well be in great disfavour in a decade or two, and it would be a pity to see a preamble to our Constitution soured by it.

I will consult widely in my own electorate because I think this has to be a very inclusive document. I think members of parliament from all parties have to listen and bring back any serious concerns about whether it has missed a particular point or whether it has set ablaze in Australia a real desire for something even more inclusive or poetic than we have got here. I think this will be the catalyst for something great if we approach it, as the previous speaker said, in an inclusive way which involves all Australians. Then and only then will I state my position on where I will vote in any referendum on the issue.

On the republic issue, I have grave misgivings about the yes case, because I do not think that those who favour a republic are clear amongst themselves about what form of republic they would like. I do not think you change a system that has worked well for a hundred years unless you can replace it with something better. I do not think that you should subject Australians to something that would be totally divisive at a time when, probably more than at any other time in our recent history, we need a sense of unity.

Having said that, while I have great respect for the Queen, both as a person and as the head of state, I do not have any fawning regard for the House of Windsor. I am more interested in the mechanisms of constitutional monarchy than I am in having some attachment to a past era. That is not where I am coming from at all. For that reason, I favour the model that the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair—a former Speaker of this House—suggested as a preliminary step to wherever else we go with this debate: to invoke an interim measure whereby, between the Governor-General and the Queen, we have a body, something like a council of state, made up of the Governor-General of the day and the six state Governors and they would take over, as it were, the powers of the Queen.

This would address the argument that we do not have an Australian head of state or that decisions regarding our Governor-General or head of state—whichever role is not important—come from some foreign country. The role of that council of state would be to confirm state governors, on the recommendation of the Premier of the particular state, or the Governor-General, on the recommendation of the Australian Prime Minister. As those governors would reflect different states of the Commonwealth and probably come from different political backgrounds, I think you would get a pretty fair assessment and we would probably end up with a continuation of the current system.

That council would have only two functions. It would appoint governors and governors-general and, if one of them were to step out of line for some reason or become incompetent to hold the office, would dismiss them. It seems to me that that would be the first step because, once you establish something like that, whether you call the role `Governor-General' or `President' would not be that important and in time, if there is a sentiment in Australia to move to a republican model, there would be a greater unity of purpose in taking the first step that way than in confronting the Australian population with something which is quite foreign to them and which, it is my belief at least, at this time in the debate is likely to be voted down.

So this is a very important bill that we have before us. It is the bill that sets up the mechanism to consider the preamble. As I said before, I hope in a most inclusive way that we do not let it become a divisive debate in itself. I think it would be regrettable if the Senate fiddled with it or blocked it. There is a mechanism under section 128 of the Constitution to bypass such a measure, but it would be regrettable if that happened. And, secondly, it sets up the mechanism fulfilling the pledge of this government that we would hold a Constitutional Convention and if there was broad unanimity of opinion from that Constitutional Convention we would put that to the Australian public at referendum. I compliment the minister on the work that has gone into this, and I hope it sets a clear format for Australia in the coming months.

talk.start.para: —The legislation before the House, the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 , is expressly designed to facilitate the passage, among other things, of the referendum on the preamble later this year. And it is on the subject of the preamble that I want to confine my remarks here tonight. The task and the test facing a Prime Minister, a poet or anyone else trying to draft a new preamble for the Australian Constitution can be very simply expressed. How do you capture in a few memorable words the essence of this country's past, present and future? I think most people would agree that a new preamble needs to be short and taut, it needs to be learnable and quotable, and it needs to touch the chords that really matter—the basic ideas that are at the heart of the kind of country we want to be and which cry out for expression.

speech.para: The style in which it is all expressed really does matter. Any constitution is, in a sense, its country's autobiography. It is a nice expression that—`the constitution is the autobiography of a nation'. I could not find in the library who said it first. Cheryl Saunders was kind enough to suggest that it might have been me about 20 years ago—that is the penalty you pay when you have been interested in these issues as long as I have. But the point is if you think about the Constitution as an autobiography in which we all ought to be able to find something of ourselves mirrored it is crucial that it be well and appropriately written.

As with any such work, it helps if the first lines are compelling and captivating. The present Australian Constitution is never going to make a good beach or fireside read. In literary terms what appears there—after any preamble—is already pretty much a lost cause. But that is no reason not to give a new flying start to the Constitution. In terms of content the starting point should continue to be the recommendations of last year's Constitutional Convention, which reached consensus, after all, around 10 core ideas. They included recognition of our cultural diversity, affirmation of the rule of law and representative democracy, respect for our unique land and environment and acknowledgment of the original occupancy and custodianship of Australia by Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders. Those ideas—the whole list of 10, and I have only read a few—should be embraced one way or another in the new preamble. Unless that happens—it does not have to be in precisely the same words or in as many words—the preamble will not deserve wide community support and it will not win that wide community support.

What kind of preamble have we got in mind? Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, put to the Prime Minister a couple of weeks ago a draft which was the product of quite a wide degree of consultation by me in particular not only with people on our own side but with people on the opposite side of this chamber and in the other House, indigenous leaders, leadership of the republic movement and people from the Australian constitutional foundation, who have been doing a lot of work on this issue. So it is not simply, in any sense, a partisan document. It is the product of a lot of consultation. What we have in mind is something like this:
Having come together in 1901 as a Federation under the Crown, relying on the blessing of Almighty God, and
The Commonwealth of Australia being now a sovereign democracy, our united people drawn from nations across the globe,
We the people of Australia
Proud of our diversity
Loving our unique and ancient land
Recognising Indigenous Australians as the original occupants and custodians of our land
Believing in freedom and equality, and
Embracing democracy and the rule of law
Commit ourselves to this our Constitution.

Maybe we can do a lot better than that, and with further thought, consultation and ideas—which I am perfectly happy to engage in a debate about—I am sure we probably can. But I think probably we have made a better fist of it with this kind of document, unfortunately, than the Prime Minister seems to have with the preamble that was put into the public domain today. Unhappily—and I say `unhappily' very genuinely because we would have wished it were otherwise—the document that has come to public attention today really falls short on every one of the kinds of tests that I have mentioned. There are some good individual phrases—as you would expect from the involvement of a poet of Les Murray's stature—but I have to say the overall effect is like wading through porridge. Some of the text is simply unintelligible. The first sentence, for example, states:
. . . the Commonwealth of Australia is constituted by the equal sovereignty of all its citizens.
The second sentence:
The Australian nation is woven together of people from many . . . arrivals.

You sort of get the drift of what is intended here, but this is no language known to man or woman, and it is certainly not the English language.
