But members will remember that in 1996 the Australian government got into a terrible mess with regard to its relationship with China. The catalyst for that was principally the abolition of the DIFF scheme. That is not a matter for this debate; it is a separate issue. But it was a disastrous deci sion and disastrously implemented. It did significant damage to our relationship with China.

That was compounded by other decisions, including that by the then Minister for Defence. There was a serious problem in Australia's relations with China, a very important trading partner for this country and a very important regional country with whom we must have the best possible relations. It is also a very important member of APEC. During 1996 we found the then reasonably newly elected—although it was not immediately after the election—Minister for Trade, Mr Fischer, on a visit to China. He was embarrassed by the fiasco the government had created by scrapping DIFF and was anxious to create an environment of cooperation in trade.

He fell for the oldest Chinese government demand in the book. Any of us who have been to China representing the government of Australia, particularly those who have been as not only trade ministers but also industry ministers, prime ministers, deputy prime ministers and foreign ministers, had all received representations for decades wanting to see this question of the way Chinese products were assessed for anti-dumping cases changed. The Chinese government were mounting very powerful arguments. It was true that domestic circumstances in China were changing and that the basis for the previous operation was at some stage in the future going to need to be reviewed, certainly if China came into the World Trade Organisation.

No other country had made any move in that direction. There was no objective evidence to suggest that the domestic market situation in China was such that that change was appropriate in these circumstances. But what did we find? In a private meeting with the Chinese government—I suspect with the very persuasive then Chinese trade minister with whom I had years of dealing, Madam Wu, and other representatives of the Chinese government—Mr Fischer agreed to treat one particular Chinese product as coming from a free market in future anti-dumping cases. We really do not know what Mr Fischer said to the Chinese or why he said it because he refused to make any explanation about it.

What we do know is that, as a consequence, Australia would be treating China in a way that no other country in the world was willing to do. The position was overwhelmingly that only when China was accepted in the WTO would it be treated as a free market. When the implications of Mr Fischer's botch-up were realised, the government attempted to back-pedal by introducing a case by case arrangement. But this was not the end of the mess. Further problems arose, and this is how they arose. The new arrangements were first exercised in the case of glyphosate, a product that is used in herbicides like Round-up and Zero. The overwhelming evidence was that the export and domestic pricing of glyphosate from China was government controlled. Yet, despite this evidence, the government determined that China was a free market and therefore glyphosate was allowed to be dumped into this country from China.

The Australians who were buying it, of course, were very happy. This is always the case with dumping: for it to be bought at that reduced price, someone in the country must like it; if they did not like it, they would not be buying it at that reduced price. There would be no dumping if no-one in the country were buying it, therefore some people were happy. But the whole international trading arrangements based on solid anti-dumping criteria—which are not unique to Australia; every country has such arrangements—were being undermined.

This had the inevitable consequence: a potential investment by Monsanto in manufacturing glyphosate in Australia worth $80 million was lost to Argentina, along with hundreds of jobs. Glyphosate is a product that was manufactured in Australia but is no longer manufactured in Australia.

To add insult to injury, once this product was allowed into Australia from China, Chinese importers pointed out what the government should always have known; it was common knowledge: the government had no legal capacity to apply the case by case approach it envisaged. That is, once one product had been treated as coming from a free market, all products needed to be treated in the same manner. Folly compounded by folly; error compounded by error.

This is the mess that must be addressed by this legislation. It is a pretty sorry story. But, given the seriousness of the mess that the government itself created, the extensive delay there has been in addressing it is truly extraordinary. The original bills were introduced in June 1997; that was more than six months after the Tim Fischer botch-up. Even then, the legislation was not brought on for debate until November—a very leisurely approach to a problem that was causing serious difficulties for Australian industry. So that legislation sat in the House of Representatives for about six months.

During that time the government did more work on its bills as industry took it to task over their inadequacies. As a result of industry lobbying and pressure being applied by the opposition—in particular, as I have said, by my colleague the member for Hotham—the government introduced amendments to the original bills to rectify some, but not all, of the inadequacies of those bills.

The then opposition recognised that it was now becoming urgent to pass the bills and deliver to industry some certainty after such a prolonged period of delay. So we did not oppose the bills, even though we believed there were inadequacies. Even then, the government could not take the hint. The amended bills went across to the Senate, where they lingered on the Notice Paper. They were never considered by the Senate prior to the October election, so the bills lapsed.

This is not a case of Senate obstruction. The government never introduced the legislation. The Senate did not have a chance to obstruct it. We would have voted for it. All the government had to do was introduce it. We had said that we would vote for it. I do not know whether the government has worked this out yet: if we vote for it, it does not matter what the minor parties and Senator Harradine do as we comprise 65 votes out of 76.

talk.start.para: —We do?

—Even at the New South Wales ALP conference, you get things carried with 65 votes out of 76. I say that for the benefit of my good friend the member for Banks, who has not yet worked out how to get things carried at the New South Wales conference, so I thought I would advise him.
—I am sure that the honourable member for Fraser will come back to the bill.

—That was very relevant to a very important point but—you are right, Madam Deputy Speaker—a different point. We had the situation where, two years after the initial problem, the government had still not addressed the issue. Now, nearly 2½ years after the initial problem, the government is introducing this legislation which is virtually identical to that which sat in the Senate for so long.

speech.para: It would be an understatement bordering on the absurd to say that the government has an unhappy record in this matter. I only hope that, once these bills have been dealt with by the House, the government in the Senate will move quickly. But I have to say that the sequencing of these bills does not give us much confidence that the government will get them into the Senate in time for consideration before Easter. Then the Senate will be up. We will be back in April, but we will be caught up in the GST bills. When is the government going to get this package through?

However, we are offering our less than enthusiastic support for this legislation. The extraordinary thing is that, although the government has had all this time, it still has not got the legislation right. As I have said before, we are strongly of the view, as I believe are most of industry, that this legislation is still inadequate in several important aspects. I do not want anyone to be under the misapprehension that, because we are not opposing these bills, we think the government has it right. We do not think the government has it right. We have said time and again that the government has not got it right. Industry does not think the government has it right.

We are not opposing these bills simply because we accept that industry deserves an outcome now. It has had to put up with lingering uncertainty for long enough, and we are not going to be the cause of more uncertainty. We were not the cause of the delay and uncertainty last year, we were not the cause of the problem in 1996 and we will not be the cause of a delay now. In so far as there are inadequacies in the legislation, the government should bear the responsibility. It has had the time and opportunity to fix the inadequacies; it has failed to do so and we are not going to clean up after it.

It is interesting to note that, when the government first introduced these bills in 1997, industry raised four concerns with the proposed special approach for determining the normal value of goods imported, for example, from China. The government has failed effectively to address these concerns.

The first industry concern in 1997 was that a price control situation, which is one of the features of the bill, was not taken to exist where government controlled or substantially controlled or influenced more than 10 per cent of the costs of inputs to production. Industry wanted this to be included. This bill has at least dealt with this issue in part by defining a price control situation to include cases where a raw material input to the good which accounts for more than 10 per cent of the costs of producing or manufacturing the good is supplied by a state owned enterprise. But that is so inadequate that anybody could get around it, and they will.

This is a very narrow definition on two counts. First, it is confined to raw material inputs only. Therefore, it does not include processed inputs, like steel or componentry. So, if a government owned coalmine supplies more than 10 per cent of input costs, this is treated as a price control situation. But, if a government owned component manufacturer provides more than 10 per cent of input costs, this is not treated as a price control situation. It would be obvious to anybody that this is an anomalous situation which should have been addressed. Let me explain its significance for the House.

What we have is a circumstance where sometimes at least it is very difficult in non-market economies to determine a fair market price for a product for the purpose of com parison with export prices. Because of the circumstance the government has put us in, we have to try to establish an objective set of criteria that will enable us to establish circumstances where the domestic price is not considered a fair market price. This is a layman's interpretation, but this is what we are trying to achieve.

One of those circumstances is where government control over the cost of inputs is such that effectively it can distort the market activity in the domestic market. Why would it be the case that that sort of impact on raw materials of 10 per cent of cost might—and probably would—affect the domestic price in such a way as to make it not a fair comparison for the purposes of comparing an anti-dumping action, but when they have the same control over equally significant prices of a different character it does not count? All that you can conclude is that someone is trying to make sure that these anti-dumping provisions do not work. Because there are those who conclude that anti-dumping is really an artificial barrier to trade and that we should welcome dumping because it means prices come in cheaper and domestic Australian users, consumers or manufacturers can take advantage of a cheaper product. But nowhere in the world is it accepted—even advocates of free markets of which I am one do not accept it—that you can allow this sort of predatory pricing to occur so that your domestic market is destroyed. The great free markets of the world do not accept this proposition and nor should they.

What is the second problem that the industry raised? The new provision is confined to inputs supplied by a state owned enterprise. This is the second part of what is wrong with the definition of the first inadequacy of the bill. It is confined to inputs supplied by state owned enterprises but does not extend to situations where the price of the input is substantially controlled by the government. This means the provision applies where the domestic price is effectively fixed because it is supplied by a state owned enterprise—but that is of decreasing significance in China now—but not where the price is directly fixed by the government or where the price is effectively fixed because of government restrictions on selling in the domestic market or government restrictions on the quantity of goods manufactured in the domestic market. It is another anomalous situation which does not take account of the real world conditions which prevail in the circumstances in which this provision is meant to apply.

The second industry concern in 1997 was that a price control situation was defined as one in which the domestic selling price of the goods is controlled or substantially controlled by government. Industry wanted the definition to include situations where the price is directly or indirectly controlled or substantially controlled or substantially influenced by government. This concern has not been addressed in the current bill. There were some options open to the government as to how they could have responded to this question of the impact of government involvement in markets in countries—in particular in China but in any country in which this law might apply—where the influence of government distorts the fair market price. This concern has not been addressed in the current bill at all. It was not addressed in the 1997 provisions. It is not addressed here.

The third industry concern in 1997 was that industry wanted to include a regulation making power to allow the minister to make regulations deeming price control situations. This has not been addressed at all. The fourth concern in relation to the 1997 bills—and it applies equally here—was that where a price control situation did exist industry wanted the minister to use the surrogate country method, but the bill proposes that the minister should have an option of using any other method undefined to determine the normal value of the allegedly dumped goods.

The surrogate method is not perfect, but it gives everybody some confidence because we have all been using that for a very long time. Anti-dumping in Australia has always used it. Every other country's anti-dumping regime uses that model. People know what it means. It gives certainty and confidence. It is not a perfect method, but it is an understood, manageable, comprehensible method. If you are planning your industry, you know the circumstances in which you are operating. Under this bill, the minister still has the discretion to use some other undefined, unknown, unmeasured method. You can see that industry has a number of concerns.

Anti-dumping arises in industries almost by definition that are in a fragile situation. If we have a healthy, vibrant domestic market, the people who sell into it do not dump. They sell at the highest price they can get. You do not get anti-dumping when the domestic market is ripping along and all the domestic industries are doing really well. Why would someone come in and sell below the market price? They are just reducing their return. What you get almost without question other than in the most extraordinary of circumstances is that anti-dumping occurs when the domestic industry is already under pressure. So there is competition for market share. The people who are affected are almost exclusively experiencing difficulties. I know you can find circumstances where this is not the case, where there is predatory pricing of someone coming in trying to capture an otherwise buoyant market, but that is unusual. International people seeking to sell their product usually would not need to dump in a healthy, buoyant domestic market because there would be enough demand for them to sell into that market, and they would be able to get the high domestic price that the domestic producers are getting. Therefore, they would get a bigger return. So why would they come here and sell for less?

The circumstance is that this almost exclusively happens when the domestic industry is in trouble. What we have here is a failure to respond to the legitimate concerns of Australian industry that is seeking assistance when it is at its most vulnerable and when it is being subjected to unfair trading practices. This is not about protectionism because the government are not saying we should not have an anti-dumping regime. They are claiming that this is re-establishing the strength of our anti-dumping regime. But what we all know is that the government created this problem, and they have failed to address it adequately.

Given this catalogue of unaddressed concerns, there is no doubt that the industry has every reason to be disappointed with the government's handling of this very important issue, and it is not surprising that they are disappointed. The industry had to watch aghast as the trade minister bungled in China and created the problem which must now be fixed. They then had to wait for six months before the government got around to addressing the mess they had created. They have now had to wait another two years before this legislation is before us. There is still no certainty of the timetable by which it will be passed, even though the opposition has supported its support for the legislation and will vote for it. To rub salt in the wounds, that outcome does not even address all of the industry's legitimate concerns.

We have before us a sorry tale. It is one that the industry have come to accept from this government. It is not surprising that they are disappointed with this package. To reiterate, the opposition will not be opposing the bills. We said in November 1997 that we would not oppose these bills.

To the extent that they are an improvement on the original legislation introduced by the government, that is a victory for my colleague the member for Hotham and, more particularly, for the industry who campaigned for these changes. They have not achieved everything that they wished but they have improved the legislation a bit. The bills are needed. The industry needs some certainty.

I wish the bills were better; I would support them with more enthusiasm. But it is time to move on. It is time to get this legislation and this problem behind us—at least to the extent that this legislation does that. To the extent that inadequacies continue to show up, as I think they will, we will find that the blame will be in only one quarter—it will be on the government. The opposition will not be opposing these bills. They are inadequate but they are the only opportunity that industry has to get any certainty, so we will allow their passage.

talk.start.para: —I note the member for Fraser said that the opposition does not plan to object to the Customs (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1998 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 before the parliament. I will comment on some of the concerns that he presented through my contribution.

speech.para: The Customs (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1998 seeks to amend the Customs Act 1901 to provide for a special approach to determining the normal value of allegedly dumped goods from countries transitioning from command to market economies. Specifically, the bill creates a new method for calculating the normal value of goods thought to be dumped in Australia from an economy in transition where state owned businesses supply more than 10 per cent of the costs of production as raw materials or where there remain government price controls over domestic selling prices of those goods.

The bill also tidies up provisions that govern the collection of interim dumping and countervailing duties as well as some language inconsistencies which have been identified. These changes, and the changes the government introduced last year, are necessary because the legislation was both prescriptive and restrictive in that it required Customs to treat transitioning economies like free market economies even in situations where the central government still had effective control over many industries and large sections of the economy. The provisions allows Customs to use an alternative or surrogate pricing model for determining the normal value of goods by reference to the selling prices of like goods in a substitute or surrogate country.

For the people of Dunkley, this bill ensures that the textile, clothing and footwear manufacturers and the automotive component manufacturers that are active, alive and well in the electorate have a significant opportunity not only to maintain their domestic share of the market in Australia but also to provide the foundation from which to expand overseas. This bill ensures that a significant portion of the manufacturing sector have greater protection against cheap imports dumped on Australian markets. It also picks up some issues that directly relate to economies in transition.

These latest proposed changes to the Customs Act 1901 came about because of recommendations made by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, and the member for Fraser mentioned some of those concerns earlier. In particular, the committee recommended that the legislation be flexible enough to allow Customs to use alternative tools, including the surrogate markets model we spoke of earlier, to establish the normal value of raw material inputs used in the production of goods allegedly dumped in Australia or where those goods have inputs that are supplied by a state owned enterprise.

Unlike what the member for Fraser said, it is not a requirement that both of those triggers be activated for the provisions of the bill to be introduced. We do not require both a 10 per cent share of raw inputs as part of the total cost of goods and that raw materials be supplied by an enterprise which is wholly owned by a national or provincial government—it is either/or. In his remarks the member for Fraser seemed to miss the fact that it is either the input trigger or the state control pricing trigger that can activate anti- dumping action; it is not a combination of both. Some of those concerns about which the member for Fraser was expressing deep regret that the government had not picked up have been picked up, and flexibilities have been provided within the amendment to make sure that other changes within the market are also accommodated. So it is an either/or trigger. There is not a requirement for both.

The other thing that the member for Fraser said, which he might wish to consider in light of what is actually in the bill, is that the raw material definition extends to raw inputs. Let us use steel for instance: it is not as if you need the ore; it is not iron ore being owned by a state owned enterprise, it is steel that would meet those classification definitions. So, again, evidence of flexibility in the provisions of the bill.

In correcting the member for Fraser's misunderstanding, I think we wipe out all four of the concerns he mentioned. The opposition is probably not opposing the bill because those concerns are not valid. The surrogate pricing tool is not obliged to be utilised where there is the state control of prices, but it is one tool. The bill is also an example of the need for flexibility in dealing with some of the cute and clever developments that the member for Fraser quite rightly pointed to. For instance, there are attempts to suggest that products are coming from a wholly owned national or provincial government enterprise. That was the basis for engaging in remedial action under this anti-dumping bill.

What if the provincial, state or national government said, `But we've got a joint venture partner'? It might own less than one per cent, but under the definitions of this act it is not a provincial or state owned enterprise. That is more evidence of the need for flexibility that this bill represents and provides Customs. So the four concerns that the member for Fraser talked about are non-concerns. The reason that the opposition is not voting against this bill is that they are non-concerns and there is no basis to oppose the bill. I am pleased that I have had the opportunity to clarify the misunderstandings of the member for Fraser.

The provisions relating to government enterprises supplying raw materials for more than 10 per cent of the value of alleged dumped goods require the minister to be satisfied that that is the case. There are opportunities for the minister to look at ways of calculating a normal price. I mentioned the surrogate country model that is available. The surrogate pricing tool can also be applied to remove the distortion of the state controlled pricing of goods. An artificially subsidised domestic price is no way to justify artificially subsidised prices for the same goods entering our markets. This is why we have gone to the surrogate pricing tool as one of a range of options that is available to Customs. Again, it is a very wise and sound improvement on the earlier bill.

Representatives of the textiles, clothing and footwear industry in particular raised this issue during the Economics Legislation Committee investigation. The industry made the point that anti-dumping legislation should acknowledge not only the normal cost of the final product but also the major raw materials consumed and involved in the production of the final product in determining whether goods have been dumped. A recent anti-dumping case highlighting the situation regarding raw materials involved woven blankets from China. There is a readily identifiable world price for yarns used in blanket manufacturing. The comparative cost advantage does not play a large part in the product manufacturing cost in the case of blankets. In many cases, the cost of the fabric can represent more than 50 per cent of the cost of manufacture of the goods. The conversion to a blanket, while requiring more labour, is still not labour intensive.

Chinese manufacturers have been able to provide Customs with documents indicating that their costings for raw materials is much cheaper than the prevailing world price and reflects internal Chinese costs. That is evidence of the need for the provisions in this bill. These costs, whether internal or reflecting purchases of fibres or partly processed material from state owned enterprises, have no relevance to international market determined prices that commercial manufacturers operating in this country must realise in their selling prices.

The changes in this bill ensure that Australian businesses have some protection from inherent subsidisation by governments in centrally controlled and transition economies. Because the clothing and textiles industry is so dependent on seasons and because the majority of the commercial activity in the industry is carried out in the Northern Hemisphere, Australia becomes an attractive destination for clearing out-of-season goods, sometimes well below costs. Again, our geography, climate and seasons being the reverse of the northern hemisphere highlights the need for the mechanisms contained in this bill today.

Because some sectors of the industry are labour intensive and in particular make use of large pools of unskilled and semiskilled labour, it is an industry that many command and transition economies have traditionally subsidised through various direct and indirect methods. Giving Australian Customs the flexibility to establish an accurate normal value for goods will ensure that Australia's anti-dumping policy does what it is designed to do, which is to protect Australian industries from unfair assaults on our local markets without causing an unfair disadvantage for Australian consumers and Australian industry, which relies on imported raw materials for local manufacturing.

The Dunkley electorate in the Mornington Peninsula region in Victoria in general is home to a large number of micro and small businesses. Because they are small, they are vulnerable to damage in their revenue base and market share from imports dumped on Australian markets below cost. One such business is the Seaford manufacturer of women's cardigans, jumpers and suits, David Keys. It once had many more staff than it has today. The business is still a vibrant business operating in the Hartnell Drive industrial precinct. For 45 years, it was a supplier to Coles Myer and David Jones. Today, the goods it used to supply are mainly sourced from Chinese manufacturers, which is much to my regret, although we are working on it.

David Keys finds itself paying a higher price for yarn than many overseas competitors. Ironically, some Australian mills sell yarn for export prices at below what the Australian textile manufacturers pay locally. That might be something for us to look at on another day. In many cases, it is cheaper to bring in completed goods. But for manufacturers like David Keys, quality is more important than dollars. That is part of its strategic plan to secure its place with the support of the government's textiles, clothing and footwear industry package.

The company has not entered what it believes would be a readily available export market because it simply does not have access to the capital required for start-up. The company has reorientated its business to smaller boutique retailers but fears that the big retailers will eventually swamp those retailers as well. China has done very well at mass producing product for the big chain stores in Australia. This has left traditional local suppliers out in the cold, unable to compete on price and at the same time maintain their quality advantage.

Another local manufacturer, BTR Automotive, which employs about 4,000 people in Victoria and quite a few who call Dunkley home, has to constantly be on the look-out for cheap and inferior raw materials as it strives to ensure that all its automotive component products are world-class and competitive in dollar terms. There have been recent successful anti-dumping actions relating to polypropylene, fibreglass, glass, polystyrene and PVC. These successful actions show that Australian regulations are having an effect and are providing the better protection that the industry needs. But we can make them even better.

I am looking through the material provided to me by the Minister for Justice and Customs. I note that a number of areas where there have been successful actions are directly impinging on the motor vehicle component sector and the BTR manufacturing outfit in the electorate of Dunkley. Looking through the list, I see that some of them include PVC from command economies such as China. A number of self-proclaimed free trade exporters, such as Canada, Japan, France, Brazil and the USA, also crack it for a mention. Action against the dumping of polystyrene resin from Korea has also attracted support from local motor vehicle component manufacturers in the Dunkley electorate.

For BTR Automotive, the challenge is to compete with the raw material input costs that are sometimes 50 per cent of the value of their goods. This can be significant if the raw materials are sourced from a government owned plant that is able to supply the materials at prices that are not available to the domestic manufacturers on free market terms. This is particularly critical to the automotive sector where quality and consistency of the finished product are critical to retaining long-term supplier contracts, and I have heard a number of colleagues in this place talk about the exacting demands and cost-down requirements of vehicle assemblers. So they are battling on all fronts to keep their head above water, but they are doing very well.

I am told that the greatest threat to the long-term future of both the small TCF and automotive industries in Dunkley is the increased use of non-tariff barriers by countries that are looking for new and more devious ways of protecting their industry. There is one country that I will not mention here where, I am told reliably by people active in the motor vehicle industry, you do not have a job with a competing manufacturer if you happen to drive a motor vehicle imported from another country. I am not quite sure how our officials would canvass addressing those issues, but it is a difficult climate out there and we have to make the best of it.

It is interesting that, when you look at these provisions and you see that the government is addressing distortions inspired by government on the cost of goods, you think that maybe in the longer term we will be back here talking about similar government inspired distortions of the cost of goods as they relate to the Kyoto agreement. We will be competing with nations that are producing product that our manufacturers produce but overseas suppliers act without the disciplines that come with our climate control compliance requirements. We might be back here for a further discussion.

Australia has long been a proponent of free markets, but that does not mean we cannot provide appropriate and proper protection to Australian industries from injurious dumping practices. This bill, which I understand is WTO friendly—for the benefit for the member for Fraser—completes the changes this government has already made to Australia's anti-dumping legislation and provides Customs with added flexibility to ensure that Australian businesses get a fair go in markets here at home.

Trade is good. Trade is something that improves our living standards. Trade is something that enables us to take advantage of our nation's strengths and what we do well. Trade is a way of carving out new opportunities for the future in our country. But it is a jungle out there. There are no `reserved for Australia' signs in international markets—for our products or our services—but, when people overseas look at the strength of our domestic economy, it must be tantalisingly attractive to get a piece of what is on offer in the Australian economy.

We know that fair trade is important to our future success, but wishing for fair trade just is not enough. We need to act, and this bill before the House is evidence that the government is acting and providing the confidence for local manufacturers to invest and continue to call Australia home for their production systems.

While we talk about the TCF industries, I am aware that there is a local footwear manufacturer in my electorate which is very keen to look at further investment in the Dunkley electorate to maintain its competitiveness. I will be very active in making sure that the TCF Strategic Investment Program meets its needs and is able to play a role in establishing Dunkley as a great place to do business whether it be for tourism, for retail, for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries or for the magnificent wine industry on the Mornington Peninsula.

The electorate of Dunkley is certainly open for business. There are a number of government policies that are helping to promote jobs in the electorate of Dunkley. The low interest rates are giving encouragement and support for our local businesses, particularly the manufacturing sector. We have specific programs in place that target key employers in the Dunkley electorate—that is, the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and the motor vehicle industry, which has a strong component of manufacturing activity in the electorate.

We have many top and high end elaborately transferred manufacturers operating in the Dunkley electorate who appreciate the skills that are available from the Dunkley community. There are very talented and gifted people living in the electorate, and I am not just saying that because a majority of them voted for me at the last election. They are very talented, gifted and productive people.

For anyone listening to this broadcast tonight, if you are looking for somewhere to invest, if you are looking for a magnificent environment where you have the joy of Port Phillip Bay on your doorstep, a wonderful supply of skilled labour in both the trades and professional sector, we have it all. We have terrifically affordable housing and a wonderful array of housing types. We are where the Melbourne metropolitan sprawl stops and that beautiful place where I think everybody needs to go to recharge—the Mornington Peninsula—begins. It is the playground of Melbourne. Some 3½ million people in Melbourne look to the Mornington Peninsula to breathe, to recharge their batteries, to appreciate and, in some respects, to admire the wonderful lifestyle that those of us who live down there enjoy.

There are a number of other exciting initiatives that the government has introduced to make sure that trade, commerce and enterprise are supporting the Dunkley electorate. Minister Reith's fair trading package looks at making sure our micro and home businesses have a fair go when they are dealing with larger enterprises. The reforms that were inspired by Minister Reith in the retail sector are very good for the many tenants of the major shopping centres in the electorate of Dunkley. That is good news for those retailers. It contrasts very starkly, though, with the efforts of those opposite to try to end youth wages. Youth wages are an important element in providing employment opportunities in the retail sector in Dunkley.

In closing, both sides of this parliament support this bill. We have heard from the member for Fraser that the opposition intends to vote for the bill. I have explained in my contribution that the concerns he raised are counterfeit. They have been addressed in the bill. The flexibility is there to deal with the changing circumstances of commercial trade, the changing attitudes and, in some cases, the devious practices of those who seek to compete with our local manufacturers for the strong growing domestic market that is available here. Australia's economy is a good news story. It must be a tantalising picture for those who are producing goods overseas to see the strength in our economy and the market opportunities that are there. We need to make sure our local manufacturers compete on fair grounds. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I wish to state my concern at the lack of support given to clients of Centrelink who contact the agency to notify it of changes in their circumstances. Over the past six months, since becoming the member for Canning, I have found there has been a continual stream of people to my office needing help in their dealings with Centrelink. The first problem is that of access. The decision was taken by the federal coalition government to close the Centrelink offices in Pinjarra and Armadale. For the people of Pinjarra and the surrounding areas it is now necessary to travel to Mandurah to have an appointment at Centrelink. This is difficult, however, as there is no public transport available.

speech.para: The other major problem is the cuts that have been made to Centrelink. There has been a reduction of resources and staff. As most constituents do everything in their power to inform Centrelink of changes in their circumstances, they become frustrated and angry when their information is not recorded accurately and they end up in debt because of this, or their payments are changed suddenly and they find that they are in dire financial straits because of the amended payments.

Mr Davies of Gosnells approached my office with paperwork which proved that on numerous occasions he had contacted Centrelink to tell them that he was no longer qualified for Austudy and was now in full-time employment. Despite this, his payments continued and he now has a debt of $1,118. He is faced with an interest charge of 20 per cent on top of this if he does not pay immediately. Mr Davies is further upset that not once has he ever received an apology despite his diligently supplying the correct information to Centrelink at all times.

Another case in my electorate is that of a gentleman from Armadale who was on a mature age partner allowance and found a job. He kept Centrelink informed of his payment details and some weeks later his wife received a letter stating that she was eligible for an aged pension. More letters came from Centrelink asking for information, which the couple had already supplied. They were very confused by all the paperwork and their daughter undertook to sort the problems out with Centrelink. She was told that her mother now had a debt of $444 due to overpayments, because the wrong box had been ticked on the computer, and that her pension would be reduced to repay the debt. The next correspondence from Centrelink was that she would not receive any payment for six weeks until the whole debt had been paid. Once again no apology was forthcoming.

The amount of paperwork required to correctly obtain payments is daunting and means that people are forced into a position where errors are made and then they need to repay the money that they should never have received. It seems that, although information is given regularly to the Centrelink offices, it is not always recorded promptly and accurately, which leads to errors in payments and further stress for Centrelink clients. People feel that there are not enough staff to cope with the demands on them.

Another example of the needless stress put on people was given to me when a couple approached me late last year. They have a disabled daughter who was turning 17 and leaving school. She had received the forms necessary to apply for the common youth allowance. This young woman had become disabled after a severe illness when she was eight, and there is no chance that her condition will ever improve. To change from the common youth allowance to a disability pension, the parents were having to take their daughter to a series of specialists to `re-prove' that she had a disability and was entitled to that pension. It is difficult enough for the parents to deal with the problems their daughter is going to encounter on a daily basis without having to go through the painful process of proving again that their child is disabled.

The vast majority of people who have approached my office with problems with Centrelink have not deliberately set out to mislead so that additional payments are received. They are typically people who do their best to comply with all the conditions put upon them to ensure that their payments are accurate and timely. The staff at Centrelink offices are under increased pressures with the decrease in staff numbers and the number of offices. They are in a position of trying to help people with one hand tied behind their backs. The federal government should allocate the resources necessary to ensure that those receiving payments who need to deal with Centrelink offices are not forced into a position of being unable to get the help and advice they need.

talk.start.para: —I would like to pay tribute tonight to a couple of clubs in the area of Ipswich in my electorate that have been doing very well and have been performing a very important service in our community, creating a bit of innovation and a bit of employment along the way. Some time ago Queensland's Goss state government introduced poker machine legislation. From the start that particular legislation was ineffective in that it wound up producing some great disparities in the performance of clubs and in the impact on hotels and the community.

speech.para: Ever since that decision to introduce those poker machines, we have been playing catch-up in Queensland. We have seen the situation of a lucky few clubs making an absolute fortune. For anyone who has seen the performance of the Broncos it is hard to equate them in the same category as a struggling RSL club or something like that in our community, yet to all intents and purposes the Broncos are a club just the same as any one of these other clubs.

In the latest effort to try and iron out the problems with the gaming machine legislation, the Beattie government have proposed retrospective legislation to outlaw a few of the shared revenue agreements that have been developed by many of the struggling clubs as a way of finding their way into the winner's circle as far as the revenue generated by poker machines is concerned.

I want to congratulate the state government because they have actually made a decision that will benefit our community. Having said that they intended to introduce retrospective legislation and, in effect, to take apart some of the clubs that are organising these shared agreements, we have had a decision in the case of the Ipswich Jets club that the government are going to reverse that earlier decision and allow the club to continue operating for five years.

So they have a five-year exemption from the retrospective legislation that would have outlawed shared agreements. And, believe you me, if that had gone ahead, the impact on the Ipswich Jets Rugby League Club would have been dramatic. We would have seen all the poker machines being dragged out the door on trolleys and the whole box and dice boarded up and closed down. The impact would have been quite significant. But what happened in the interim was that membership of the Ipswich Jets Rugby League Club absolutely skyrocketed.

The Ipswich Jets has been a struggling club for many years, and the decision for them to enter a shared agreement with the Victorian company, Tabcorp, was quite a significant one. They took that step—they were taking quite a bold step—and the decision meant that they wound up with a club that really was quite an entertainment venue and they were able to provide more revenue to fund their forays into the rugby league competition—the Queensland rugby league. Overall, it was quite a positive move, and the membership of that club soared to more than 9,000 in four or five weeks. So there was a huge community expression of support for the Ipswich Jets Rugby League Club. The disappointment, though, when the government was intending to move ahead with this retrospective legislation was quite concerning, and the decision now to go back on that decision is certainly welcomed.

Because of that revenue from the poker machines, the Ipswich Jets Rugby League Club has been able to create employment in north Ipswich for 35 Ipswichians. On a wider scale, you might say that that does not sound like a lot but, believe you me, in north Ipswich that is quite significant. That is an area that has been struggling, and it is a welcome outcome. If only the Ipswich Jets could replicate their performance in the business arena on the playing field, we really would have something to crow about.

One of the concerning aspects, though, is that the ramifications of being able to pursue a shared poker machine agreement have not been extended to other local clubs. I believe that those types of agreements need not be overbearing as far as clubs are concerned. In fact, in many cases I believe they can be quite beneficial. I think that the state government should take that into account when they are looking at the impact of poker machines, because if they can harness the competitive ability of these small clubs and put them up against some of these big clubs, then I think we would have greater employment, more benefits and the opportunity for the larger clubs to contribute more to the general community. I congratulate the Jets on their success. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Integral to the purchase by the Moorabbin Airports Corporation of a long-term lease over the Moorabbin Airport in Melbourne's south-eastern suburbs from the federal government, is that an airport use draft master plan is to be developed. The Moorabbin Airports Corporation is responsible for on-the-ground activities and Airservices Australia is responsible for airborne activities in the airport environs.

speech.para: The draft master plan has been prepared pursuant to the Airports Act 1996, and its aim is to charter the development of an airport of regional and state significance over the next 20 years. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services is soon to consider the master plan, and I urge him to do so principally with a view to lowering noise levels over the surrounding residential areas.

I am concerned that the minister is to consider a draft master plan which, despite the proximity of residential areas on each side of the airport, proposes an unacceptable ceiling of 440,000 general aviation and 12½ thousand regular public transport movements per year, and extensions to the main runway to accommodate modern regional jet aircraft engaged in regular public transport operations. This total of 452,500 aircraft movements per annum is an increase in the current level of 340,000 aircraft movements per annum.

The Moorabbin Airport Residents Association has indeed been an effective voice in advancing safety considerations for residents and achieving decreases in aircraft noise levels. MARA has enjoyed a very productive relationship with the MAC and it has found the MAC to be both cooperative and helpful. However, MARA is of the view that the introduction of 70- to 100-seat passenger jets and an increase in the number of aircraft movements, as I say, from 340,000 to more than 452,000 annually is incompatible with the surrounding suburban environment from both a noise and a safety perspective.

MARA is also of the view that the Moorabbin airport master plan should stipulate curfews on training flying circuits, including those for helicopters, between 1830 hours and 0830 hours to reduce the noise impact on residents; and provide for the redrawing of circuit flying patterns away from residential areas and more orientated towards green belt and industrial areas. The association also contends that there must be a phasing-out of older, less environmentally sensitive aircraft, a reduction in flying for recreation and sightseeing purposes and an abandonment of formation flying. Only when these issues have been addressed can local residents accurately assess the viability of the draft master plan.

Critically, when considering the master plan and its approval, I urge the minister not to spend much time on matters relating to the commercial and industrial development around the perimeter of the airport and landscaping of the site, but rather consider in more detail issues which adversely affect the quality of life of local residents. These issues notably are noise, safety, noise, curfew arrangements and noise.

I conclude by commending the activities of MARA, in particular the commitment and dedication of its president, Mr Tom Uren, and its secretary, Miss Anna Emanuel, who have led the charge to ensure that surrounding residents on each side of the airport get a fair go and who will no doubt ensure that, in the long haul, noise levels will be reduced and safety considerations will be put at the forefront of the mind of the minister.

talk.start.para: —Just before Christmas last year I thought all my Christmases had come at once. I was fortunate enough to be able to launch the Regional Home Based Business Study for the south-east region of Melbourne. It was something that I have felt very strongly about for a long time. I have been urging local councils to act on the matter of home based microbusinesses that are very much part of the electorates of Dunkley and Isaacs and the general south-east region of Melbourne. I know that this study enjoyed my support and that of the member for Isaacs and members from both sides of politics when it was launched in December.

speech.para: The study was commissioned by the City of Casey which, from all accounts, is doing an excellent job trying to stimulate economic activity in their municipality. It was funded by South East Development, the area consultative committee that operates over the south-east of Melbourne. The study was aimed principally at getting a handle on this phenomenon of home based businesses, because all the anecdotal evidence and advice coming through from the microbusiness network that Barbara Gabogrecan and others are so active in is that the micro- and home based business sector is an enormously important area of outer metropolitan economies. This is very much the case in the Dunkley electorate and on the Mornington Peninsula.

The fascinating thing about home based business surveys that were conducted in the lead-up to the preparation of the strategy is that home based businesses have a number of highly desirable characteristics which, in my view, warrant closer consideration by all levels of government. Home based businesses in the south-east region are sustainable. For example, almost 50 per cent have been in existence for five years or more and more than 40 per cent of these businesses have a turnover of more than $100,000. Almost 50 per cent of home based businesses have the intention of increasing their level of employment. That implies a potential for between 1,200 and 7,000 new jobs in the region if we can leverage home based businesses and give them the support that this study identified as being necessary.

But the highest need for home based businesses is external support. Being from the local government sector, I am familiar with the—at times—hostile attitude of some councils a number of years ago towards home based businesses, particularly if they were inappropriate home based businesses operating in residential areas and having a negative impact on the amenity of that neighbourhood. But this study identifies a large number of home based businesses that can operate and prosper in an entirely compatible arrangement with local neighbourhoods. They represent quite an exciting employment opportunity that has not been properly tapped or fully supported by any level of government. The total number of people employed in the south-east region is a tad under a quarter of a million. Those employed in home based businesses are estimated to be around 15 per cent of the total employment level. That is 35,000 to 40,000 people employed in home based businesses in the south-east region of Melbourne. That is a large number of people contributing to the local economies and a large number of home based businesses with the potential to employ more people.

A number of recommendations came out of the study focusing on external support. There were a couple of recommendations that I particularly paid attention to. One of them was the need for information. Home based businesses are generally very self-reliant in obtaining information. A number of them avoid registering with the normal institutional structures that would otherwise generate information because of fear that they would be subject to the less than welcoming treatment that a number of them have experienced in the past. Having said that, though, we need to address this information need so that microbusinesses are aware of potential customers, marketing information, government regulations and support programs and can take advantage of them.

Beyond that access to information, there is also a need for commercial support services at an appropriate scale. Some of those involve the new technologies in the Internet service area which I have been actively working at supporting, particularly with a proposal for an e-commerce summit on the Mornington Peninsula that I hope the National Office of Information Economy will get behind. Another idea that has come out of Barbara Gabogrecan's work—and I must take my hat off to her, she does an enormous amount of networking for the microbusiness community—is a home based business expo that would enable a lot of these smaller operators to come out and share the opportunities that each represents with other home based businesses in the area, to celebrate their contribution to the economy and also to take advantage of the changing ways of doing business, in particular online commerce.

The local councils need to have a look at their town planning regulations. I know Frankston City Council has already done that and I look forward to being further briefed on that. I wish the new mayor of Frankston City Council—Councillor David Dawn—well and hope I have the opportunity of discussing these matters further with him, as well as with the Mornington Peninsula Shire Council. This is an important area. I hope the government will get behind home based businesses. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There has been considerable discussion of various issues involving Perth airport recently. The issue of aircraft noise needs to be revisited. This is important to people in my constituency of Swan and I would like to foreshadow that I have on notice a private member's motion dealing specifically with this issue, which I hope to address in the near future if I can get some air time.

speech.para: I believe the government needs to establish a three part strategy. Firstly, the government needs to consider compensation under the guidelines already established in Sydney. These need to be adopted in Perth and become effective immediately. Secondly, action must be taken to re-examine the methodology for testing and apportioning the noise `footprint'. Thirdly, the government should develop a long- term plan with consideration for future development at the airport, in light of projections of increased aircraft traffic and noise. I have received many calls from residents concerned about the current level of noise, the future projections of noise as the airport develops, and what will be done to ensure the community's needs are given justifiable consideration.

To do justice to the concerns of my constituents, last week in this place I intended to raise some matters concerning the Airports Amendment Bill. The government, in its infinite wisdom, decided to stifle the debate on this matter. I also contend that the government's past performance concerning the issue of those affected by aircraft noise in Perth leads me to be pessimistic about the opportunities of open discussion on the issue of compensation. I believe that the Airservices corporation and this government need to undertake further discussions with community groups to look at what can be achieved in the near future. This parliament needs to be ready to assist in developing commensurate packages, as they have in Sydney.

Last week whilst visiting the Queens Park Primary School I had direct experience of the noise issue when attending an assembly. On three separate occasions the children had to cease speaking due to aircraft movements directly overhead. This area needs to have the current noise methodology re-examined. I find it hard to believe that the current Australian Noise Expectation Footprint, ANEF, of 20 for the primary school has been calculated accurately. Nevertheless, it is possible to see the extent of the problem when you consider that where a school has an ANEF in the 20-25 range `an analysis of building noise reduction requirements by an acoustic consultant should be made and any necessary noise control features included in the design of the building'. It is also suggested that where the ANEF is greater than 25 double glazing and insulation should be the minimum standard.

Unfortunately, at present all educational activity has to cease whenever an aircraft is overhead. Future projections put the school in the 30 to 35 ANEF bracket. Furthermore, I believe that in the latest ANEF data there are projections that list some residential areas north of the runway at 30 and even 40 ANEF and that parts of Queens Road, South Guildford are currently within the 30 to 35 ANEF boundary. Where we had 40 ANEF in Sydney the government purchased the houses in that locality because they believed that they were uninhabitable. I am also led to believe that the ANEF footprint will extend south to areas in the suburbs of Queens Park and Kewdale at a rating of 30 to 35 ANEF.

If we find that the amount of flights is to increase, plans must be made accordingly. Where alterations have to be made, we must develop a strategy to ensure the community is consulted and appropriate action taken. This means that guidelines to ensure community protection measures need to be put in place. This must be done immediately, and a monitoring strategy needs to be developed. This strategy must be implemented following public consultation and be open to modification.

Some members here will be familiar with Perth airport. It is, of course, the central hub of the aviation industry in the city, located 12 kilometres from the city centre. It also is a considerable component of the total landmass of the electorate of Swan, comprising a site of 2,105 hectares. Key information for the financial year of 1997-98 include that there were almost 3.1 million passenger movements, that the growth in international passenger traffic was five per cent and that airport tonnage was up a total of 10 per cent.

In conclusion, I have real problems with the broad thrust of the government's aircraft noise policy for Perth International Airport. This is for two principal reasons. The first is that this government needs to immediately act to ensure that the rights of residents surrounding Perth airport are protected, and the second is that the government needs to conduct a comprehensive social, economic and environmental study to examine the long-term ramifications of any expansion at Perth airport.

talk.start.para: —On 27 January Corangamite had a visit from the Hon. Mark Vaile, Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Greatly assisted in this visit were the Chairman of the Corangamite Catchment Management Authority, members of that board and other personnel throughout Corangamite who are interested in environmental matters. I wish to raise some of the issues that were raised during the very important visit by the minister.

speech.para: The minister firstly inspected the Southern Farming Systems Research Station at Gnarwarre near Geelong which raised some very interesting research matters in relation to raised bed agriculture. There is a new system of agriculture in southern Victoria, where waterlogging has been a problem. With raised bed cropping it is estimated by the research group that productivity can improve by 40 per cent. They started with some 60 farmer members in 1995, and now they have 700 members who have signed up and are part of that research project.

The raised beds improved the root structures and are able to run off the waterlogging which is a problem that emerges during the wet winters in western Victoria. Also, the raised beds helped with salting problems, which are a difficulty in most parts of rural Australia, especially in Western Australia in the Murray-Darling Basin. It was pointed out to the minister that 10 days of waterlogging could be very detrimental to the outcome of any cereal crop. It was also made very clear that cropping gross margins were well ahead of animal gross margins in western Victoria at this stage of the agricultural cycle. With the raised bed agriculture there was an attitudinal change that water was a good thing and that it should be harvested and not just wasted during the winter period.

The minister then inspected Alley Tree Farming at Mr Rowan Peel's property at Mount Pollock. This was a very interesting experiment where trees were grown 180 metres apart, utilising deep ripping, moulding and spraying, which encouraged considerable growth rates. These trees are mixed in a cropping program. They cover about 10 per cent of the paddock, and after two years the trees are about four metres high.

The minister was particularly impressed with this project, which incorporated no fences and no tree guards and had the combination, as I say, of cropping and commercial forestry farming. Globulus blue gum and spotted blue gum varieties were the basic varieties used, and the comment was made by the farmer that the visual observation of the successful project had made a big impact on the attitude of those visitors who had come to look at something that they thought almost impossible to achieve. Some 300 visitors had visited that site.

We next visited a property that had an infestation of serrated tussock—members of this House would be aware of the impact of this particular weed—and Mr Scott Chirnside, Chairman of the Victorian Serrated Tussock Task Force, informed the minister of the problems of serrated tussock. This has 80,000 seeds in one bush. It is very difficult to control, and it has a great capacity to spread in windy conditions to neighbours' properties.

It was suggested to the minister that serrated tussock should be a weed of national importance because it infests areas in the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales and Tasmania. The problems of enforcement and voluntary eradication were also raised with the minister. It was pointed out that Victorians are attacking the serrated tussock problem with a state-wide approach—unlike New South Wales who have a shire-by-shire approach. I know that the parliamentary secretary is at the moment approaching the issue of making sure that frenock is available for the eradication of serrated tussock.

This is a major national problem. Tullamarine airport is infested with serrated tussock—a weed—and many international and interstate visitors do not understand the impact that this weed might have if it is not suitably controlled. I am delighted that the minister was able to visit the electorate of Corangamite and to see these problems first-hand, and I am sure he was able to take away some impressions and some policy advice with which he might run his portfolio in a better manner, taking into account his experience.

debate.para: Mr Anderson to present a bill for an act relating to liability for certain injury, loss, damage or destruction by aircraft, and for related purposes.
Mr Costello to present a bill for an act to provide financial assistance to the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, and for related purposes.

Mr Costello to present a bill for an act to amend and to repeal the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995, to repeal the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994, and for related purposes.

(1) requests the federal Government to introduce a noise amelioration program for the Perth International Airport to address areas currently affected by aircraft noise and bring Perth International Airport within the ambit of the Aircraft Noise Levy Act 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Collection Act 1995; and

(2) calls on the Government prior to or contemporaneously with the signing of the Perth International Airport Draft Master Plan to initiate a comprehensive social, economic and environmental study to examine the longer term ramifications of any proposed expansion of the airport with a view to implementing a compensation or other noise amelioration program for areas identified as being affected.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 4.30 p.m.

debateinfo.title: ASSISTANCE FOR CARERS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Assistance for Carers Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 seeks to make a number of significant changes to the payments for people who are caring for a person in their own home. I am pleased to see that the bill contains a number of beneficial measures that will assist these carers because, when it comes down to it, these are people who are in employment, even if they are not being paid a wage for that task. Their work is often arduous and thankless and the value of the work they perform must not be underestimated in either financial or social terms.

speech.para: Carers, selfless in the work they do, are an asset in our communities, giving much more than they take. They take the burden off institutionalised care, saving governments millions. All too often, they receive little or no recognition for this. Carers do an outstanding job in our community, looking after the elderly and the disabled. It is a job which frequently has little respite, with carers having no choice but to work around the clock, seven days a week, for every week of the year. I am sure all members of the House know of many of these people and see the problems they deal with on a day-to-day basis. This is the case in my area which has one of the highest proportions of aged people in Australia. I know, from personal experience, just how carers play a very important part in assisting those who cannot look after themselves. I know that is the case for most members of this House.

With age, unfortunately, there comes a time when it is difficult to go about day-to-day activities unaided. Without the assistance of carers, most of whom are family members, many of our elderly citizens would have no choice but to move into institutionalised care. For many this transition is stressful, causing a great deal of hardship for both the individual and their family. The transition more often than not is accompanied by a deterioration in their condition as they move into unfamiliar surroundings. Without compelling medical evidence, people should have the opportunity to remain in their homes amongst familiar surroundings, with their friends and with their family. To this end, providing extra assistance to carers is indeed pivotal.

The difficulties faced by the elderly in this regard are also shared by younger people in our community who, through no fault of their own, are unable to cope with their disabilities. Providing extra assistance to their carers helps to relieve the burdens faced on a day-to-day basis by younger people with disabilities and their families. There are many beneficial measures in this bill. I believe it is appropriate to draw attention to the vast areas of unmet need in the disability sector before I deal with those in detail.

It is widely acknowledged that disability services are crying out for extra resources. In my state of Queensland, there is a package coming from the state government which will deliver substantially more. This was acknowledged by the 1997 Commonwealth, state and territory community services ministers meeting. This meeting followed a report from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare entitled Demand for disability support services in Australia. The figures for unmet needs are quite sobering. There are 13,400 people who urgently require accommodation, while 12,000 people require day or recreation activities, and 38,000 people require employment services to give them the opportunity to participate in the work force. These issues need to be addressed. This cannot be done overnight, but it has to be a high priority for government policy development. State and federal ministers agreed at this meeting I mentioned before to discuss these unmet needs, but the next meeting to do this has yet to happen. It is unfortunate that Senator Newman postponed this meeting from December last year to next month, some 12 months after it was first promised.

The demand for disability services is continuing to increase, yet, sadly, the federal government has wound back expenditure in recent years, and this has placed undue burdens on community service and disability sectors. Providing assistance to carers is important and long overdue, but for people with disabilities there are other issues that affect them on a daily basis. I am quite concerned that the government's tax package—described in the House today by the Treasurer as the ANTS package—will have a dramatic impact on people with disabilities and raise new roadblocks for them. This insidious tax not only affects them directly but also undermines the ability of not-for-profit and charitable organisations to help people with disabilities and their carers. People with disabilities have higher costs of living compared with others. In this respect, the GST will be particularly regressive in relation to their incomes, which are diminished by their inability to earn income and to do similar work to other taxpayers.

Although many disability services are GST free, many are not. For instance, a person with a disability may be unable to drive or use public transport; they have to rely on taxis, which cost a lot more. I shudder to think how much extra this necessity will cost when the GST is factored in.
Mrs Elson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They do not get vouchers for every trip they take. This is the normal cost of living. In addition to this, charitable and not-for-profit organisations, which provide assistance to people with disabilities and their carers, will have no choice but to cut valuable services with the imposition of the GST. Massive GST administrative burdens have been estimated to cost the community and charity sector between $500 million and $1 billion annually. I think that, if government members read the submissions, particularly those from the community affairs sector inquiring into this, they would be quite shocked by the impact this will have on those organisations which play such a vital role in caring for the elderly and those with disabilities. In particular, ACROD has had this to say:

speech.para: It is our considered opinion that the tax reform package will adversely affect both people with disabilities, their families and the charities which serve them.

The evidence in the Senate inquiry on this is quite compelling, and I will leave that for another day, except to make the point that, whilst there are beneficial measures in this bill, they are being introduced in an environment which will take a lot more away from carers through the government's tax package. Whilst the measures in this bill are welcome and long overdue, I think the government should reflect on the damage the GST will do.

I would now like to consider the measures contained in the bill in some detail. As I said before, whilst we support the bill, we have some serious misgivings about some of the changes it proposes. Schedule 1 of the bill empowers the government to create an adult disability assessment tool for assessing the level of a person's disability. This will replace some of the key criteria for determining entitlement to payments for people caring for those over the age of 16. We are not necessarily opposed to the movement this represents to more objective criteria for assessing disability. Our view depends entirely on the detail of the new assessment method. What we are very concerned about is that, by agreeing with this bill, we are agreeing to the introduction of an assessment tool we have not yet seen. We have seen a draft of the assessment tool but it has not yet been finalised. As the assessment tool is to take the form of a disallowable instrument, we will not be able to seek amendments to it. Our only option, if we have real problems with the instrument, is to try to have it disallowed. This is a very difficult option as the effect of the bill is that, from 1 July 1999, entitlement to certain payments cannot be assessed without the tool. Any delay in implementing the tool after that date will cause delays in assessment of entitlement.

We have had some experience with this, and this is why I raise it. I hope government members opposite take note of this, because they would have had experience with the child disability assessment tool already and seen people in their areas who have experienced severe problems with this.

The child disability assessment tool was introduced last year. I and many other members in the House have received many complaints from carers, community organisations and the medical profession about the way that this tool is operating. In the House only yesterday we had a private member's motion from the member for Braddon, Mr Sidebottom, who detailed many of the difficulties involved in this area. He was talking particularly about cystic fibrosis—and we have all had some experience with people in this position—and about returning cystic fibrosis to the list of recognised conditions contained in the child disability assessment tool.

This motion was prompted by many letters from anxious parents of cystic fibrosis sufferers and their treating doctors. I am pleased to say that the motion received support from government members, the members for Bradfield and Moore. That was good to see. I would like to quote from the speech from the member for Bradfield, Dr Nelson, in response to the motion moved by the member for Braddon, Mr Sidebottom. Dr Nelson said:

On a personal note, my experience of dealing with this disease as a paediatric registrar, as a general practitioner and as a human being is such that I believe this disease should be automatically listed for the child disability allowance.

The honourable member concluded by giving his personal support to the motion moved by the member for Braddon, Mr Sidebottom, and urged the team that is currently reviewing the tool to replace cystic fibrosis on the recognised conditions list. It appears that two government members also believe, along with members on this side, that the child disability assessment tool is inadequate in its treatment of this condition.

This is a serious issue that has been raised with us by parents and professionals since that tool commenced operation. I do not believe that the government got the child disability assessment tool right and I am now very concerned that they will not get the adult tool right either. Given our experience with the child disability assessment tool, we are concerned about taking the government on trust in this matter.

To add to these concerns, the National Epilepsy Foundation of Australia have already raised a serious issue regarding the draft adult disability assessment tool. They say that the draft does not contain enough questions about intermittent or episodic conditions, such as epilepsy, which require constant vigilance and occasional intensive care from a carer rather than constant care on a day-to-day basis. I would urge the government today to look very seriously at this issue.

Despite the serious practical problems it might cause, if the final version of the adult assessment tool is likely to lead to significant inequities, those on this side of the House and many in the community organisations that have supported the bill to this stage are going to be put, as I explained before, in a very difficult position. I would urge the government to avoid such an unfortunate possibility. I would urge the government, for example, to provide us and the community organisations with the final version of the tool as quickly as possible to give us sufficient time to consider it and to discuss any problems with the government well before 1 July. I mean that in a very genuine and bipartisan sense.
